senses.definition: any of the hard parts that form the skeleton of the body of a human or an animal

examples.x: He survived the accident with no broken bones.
This fish has a lot of bones in it.
She went for a bone density scan.
The dog was gnawing at a bone.
She had a beautiful face with very good bone structure.

senses.definition: the hard substance that bones are made of

examples.x: knives with bone handles

senses.definition: having bones of the type mentioned

examples.x: fine-boned

senses.definition: a complete change of opinion, plan or behaviour

examples.x: The government did an about-turn over nuclear energy.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something is completely true

examples.x: You're absolutely right.
He made it absolutely clear.
I'm not absolutely certain I posted it.
Are you absolutely sure?
Training is absolutely essential in this business.
Don't delay for longer than absolutely necessary.
The place was absolutely packed.
It was absolutely pouring with rain.

senses.definition: used to emphasize something negative

examples.x: That man does absolutely no work!
There's absolutely nothing more the doctors can do.

senses.definition: used with adjectives or verbs that express strong feelings or extreme qualities to mean ‘extremely’

examples.x: absolutely delighted/thrilled

I absolutely love strawberries.
She absolutely adores you.
absolutely fantastic/amazing

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you agree with somebody, or to give somebody permission to do something

examples.x: ‘They could have told us, couldn't they?’ ‘Absolutely!’

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you strongly disagree with somebody, or to refuse permission

examples.x: ‘Was it any good?’ ‘No, absolutely not.’
‘Can I stay up late?’ ‘Absolutely not!’

senses.definition: not considered in relation to other things

examples.x: White-collar crime increased both absolutely and in comparison with other categories.

senses.definition: as stated or reported by somebody/something according to

examples.x: According to Mick, it's a great movie.

senses.definition: following, agreeing with or depending on something

examples.x: The work was done according to her instructions.

senses.definition: to agree with or match something

examples.x: These results accord closely with our predictions.

senses.definition: to have the opinion that somebody/something is a particular thing

examples.x: In English law a person is accounted innocent until they are proved guilty.

senses.definition: a narrow opening in something, especially one that lets light through

examples.x: a chink in the curtains

senses.definition: a small area of light shining through a narrow opening

examples.x: I noticed a chink of light under the door.

senses.definition: the light ringing sound that is made when glass objects or coins touch

examples.x: the chink of glasses

senses.definition: directed against a person’s character rather than their argument

examples.x: an ad hominem attack

senses.definition: a person that somebody is opposed to and competing with in an argument or a battle

senses.definition: an opinion or a suggestion about what somebody should do in a particular situation Advice

senses.definition: to tell somebody what you think they should do in a particular situation recommend

examples.x: I would strongly advise against going out on your own.

senses.definition: to give somebody help and information on a subject that you know a lot about

examples.x: We employ an expert to advise on new technology.

examples.cf: advise somebody what, which, whether, etc…

senses.definition: to officially tell somebody something

examples.x: Please advise us of any change of address.

examples.cf: advise somebody when, where, how, etc…
examples.x: I will contact you later to advise you when to come.

senses.definition: to support something publicly recommend

examples.x: The group does not advocate the use of violence.

senses.definition: an affirmative word or reply means ‘yes’ or expresses agreement affirmative

examples.x: an affirmative response to the question

senses.definition: expressing something that is true, did happen, etc.; not containing words such as ‘no’, ‘not’, ‘never’, etc.

examples.x: affirmative and negative forms/sentences

senses.definition: a word or statement that means ‘yes’; an agreement or a confirmation

examples.x: She answered in the affirmative (= said ‘yes’).
She asked if he would give his support to the scheme and he answered in the affirmative.

senses.definition: in a way that means ‘yes’ or expresses agreement

examples.x: 90 per cent voted affirmatively.

senses.definition: one more time; on another occasion

examples.x: This must never happen again.

senses.definition: showing that somebody/something is in the same place or state that they were in originally

examples.x: We're very happy to be here together again.

senses.definition: added to an amount that is already there

examples.x: The cost is about half as much again as it was two years ago.

senses.definition: used to show that a comment or fact is connected with what you have just said

senses.definition: used to introduce a fact or an opinion that contrasts with what you have just said

examples.x: We might buy it but then again we might not.

senses.definition: used when you ask somebody to tell you something or repeat something that you think they have told you already

examples.x: What was the name again?

senses.definition: opposing or disagreeing with somebody/something

senses.definition: not to the advantage or favour of somebody/something

examples.x: The evidence is against him.

senses.definition: close to, touching or hitting somebody/something

examples.x: Put the piano there, against the wall.

senses.definition: in order to prevent something from happening or to reduce the damage caused by something

examples.x: an injection against rabies

senses.definition: with something in the background, as a contrast

examples.x: His red clothes stood out clearly against the snow.

senses.definition: used when you are comparing two things

examples.x: You must weigh the benefits against the cost.

senses.definition: if you include money or costs against an amount that is owed, you use it to reduce the amount against

examples.x: The accountant said I could offset all my travel costs against tax.

senses.definition: if you borrow money against property that you own, you use the value of the property as a guarantee that you will repay the money against

examples.x: They had borrowed a lot of money against the value of the house.

senses.definition: holding or showing the belief that it is not possible to know whether God exists or not
not having a strong opinion about an activity or topic

examples.x: I’m largely agnostic on this issue as I know so little about it.

senses.definition: (used about computer hardware or software) able to be used with many different types of computer systems, software or operating systems

examples.x: Now that the services are platform-agnostic, they can be accessed by far more users.

senses.definition: to have the same opinion as somebody; to say that you have the same opinion

examples.x: When he said that, I had to agree.

senses.definition: to approve of something because you think it is morally right

examples.x: I don't agree with hitting children as a punishment.

senses.definition: to say ‘yes’; to say that you will do what somebody wants or that you will allow something to happen agree

senses.definition: used when accepting thanks for help or a favour, or when somebody says they are sorry

senses.definition: used to get somebody’s attention

examples.x: At that time children were regularly beaten for quite minor offences (= as a punishment).
A man was found beaten to death.
The prisoners were beaten into submission (= they were beaten until they did what was wanted).
They beat him unconscious (= hit him until he became unconscious).
The men took him out into the street and beat him senseless.

senses.definition: to hit something hard several times beat

examples.x: Somebody was beating at the door.
Hailstones beat against the window.
Someone was beating a drum.
I was beating dust out of the rugs (= removing dust from the rugs by beating them).

senses.definition: to make, or cause something to make, a regular sound or movement

examples.x: She's alive—her heart is still beating.
His heart started beating faster.
We heard the drums beating.
The bird was beating its wings (= moving them up and down) frantically.

senses.definition: to mix something with short quick movements with a fork, etc.

examples.x: Beat the eggs up to a frothy consistency.
Beat the mixture well, until it is light and creamy.
Add three eggs, lightly beaten.
Beat the flour and milk together.

senses.definition: to change the shape of something, especially metal, by hitting it with a hammer, etc.

examples.x: The gold is beaten out into thin strips.
beaten silver

senses.definition: to make a path, etc. by walking somewhere or by pressing branches down and walking over them

examples.x: a well-beaten track (= one that has been worn hard by much use)

senses.definition: used (to ask) if somebody is upset, unhappy, etc. or if there is a problem

examples.x: What's the matter? Is there something wrong?
Is anything the matter?
Is something the matter with Bob? He seems very down.
There's something the matter with my eyes.

What's the matter with you today (= why are you behaving like this)?
What on earth was the matter with her, she wondered. She’d come here to enjoy herself and here she was, stuck on her own in the hotel.

senses.definition: a subject or situation that you must consider or deal with

examples.x: It's a private matter.
They had important matters to discuss.
She may need your help with some business matters.
financial/legal/political matters
They've agreed in theory, but now we need to discuss practical matters.
The matter should be referred to a senior manager.
Do I have any choice in the matter?
I always consulted him on matters of policy.
It's a matter for the police (= for them to deal with).
It was a matter of some concern to most of those present (= something they were worried about).
It should have been a simple matter to check.
It was no easy matter getting him to change his mind.
Let's get on with the matter in hand (= what we need to deal with now).
I wasn't prepared to let the matter drop (= stop discussing it).
We have sent these concerns to Professor Tribe, and now consider the matter closed (= it is finished).
I did not feel that we had got to the heart of the matter (= the most important part).
And that is the crux of the matter (= the most important thing about the situation).
And then there's the little matter of the fifty pounds you owe me.

senses.definition: the present situation, or the situation that you are talking about

examples.x: Unfortunately, there is nothing we can do to improve matters.
I'd forgotten the keys, which didn't help matters.
And then, to make matters worse, his parents turned up.
I decided to take matters into my own hands (= deal with the situation myself).
Matters came to a head (= the situation became very difficult) with his resignation.

senses.definition: a situation that involves something or depends on something

examples.x: Learning to drive is all a matter of coordination.

She resigned over a matter of principle.
The government must deal with this as a matter of urgency.
Just as a matter of interest (= because it is interesting, not because it is important), how much did you pay for it?
‘I think this is the best so far.’ ‘Well, that's a matter of opinion (= other people may think differently).’
It's not pure fantasy ! It's a plain matter of fact.
Getting the effect you want is a matter of trial and error.
That's not a problem. It's simply a matter of letting people know in time.
Planning a project is just a matter of working out the right order to do things in.

senses.definition: physical substance that everything in the world is made of; not mind or spirit

examples.x: to study the properties of matter

senses.definition: a substance or things of a particular sort

examples.x: Add plenty of organic matter to improve the soil.
elimination of waste matter from the body

senses.definition: to agree to a request, an idea or a suggestion

examples.x: Nobody would assent to the terms they proposed.

senses.definition: to state clearly and definitely that something is true

senses.definition: to behave in a confident and determined way so that other people pay attention to your opinions

senses.definition: to make other people recognize your right or authority to do something, by behaving in a determined and confident way

senses.definition: to start to have an effect

examples.x: He was correct in his assertion that the minister had been lying.

senses.definition: the act of stating, using or claiming something strongly

examples.x: the assertion of his authority

senses.definition: expressing opinions or desires strongly and with confidence, so that people take notice

examples.x: You should try and be more assertive.
assertive behaviour

senses.definition: in a strong and confident way, so that people take notice of what you think or want
to make a judgement about the nature or quality of somebody/something

examples.x: Accurately assessing environmental impacts is very complex.
to assess a patient’s needs

senses.definition: to calculate the amount or value of something

examples.x: They have assessed the amount of compensation to be paid.

senses.definition: an opinion or a judgement about somebody/something that has been thought about very carefully

examples.x: a detailed assessment of the risks involved

senses.definition: the act of judging or forming an opinion about somebody/something

examples.x: Objective assessment of the severity of the problem was difficult.

senses.definition: the process of testing students and making a judgement about their knowledge, ability or progress

examples.x: written exams and other forms of assessment

senses.definition: an amount that has been calculated and that must be paid

examples.x: a tax assessment

senses.definition: to make a connection between people or things in your mind

examples.x: I always associate the smell of baking with my childhood.

senses.definition: to spend time with somebody, especially a person or people that somebody else does not approve of

examples.x: I don't like you associating with those people.

senses.definition: to show that you support or agree with something

examples.x: I associate myself with the prime minister's remarks (= I agree with them).

senses.definition: a long distance away a long way

examples.x: We didn't go far.

There's not far to go now.

a concert of music from near and far

senses.definition: used when you are asking or talking about the distance between two places or the distance that has been travelled or is to be travelled

How much further is it?

senses.definition: a long time from the present; for a large part of a particular period of time

senses.definition: used when you are asking or talking about the degree to which something is true or possible

examples.x: How far can we trust him?

examples.x: How far have you got with that report?

senses.definition: the correct speed and rhythm of a piece of music

senses.definition: a position of the body

examples.x: I called heads and it came down tails.

senses.definition: the end of a long narrow object that is larger or wider than the rest of it

examples.x: the head of a nail

senses.definition: the top or highest part of something

examples.x: at the head of the page

senses.definition: the place where a river begins
the most important seat at a table

examples.x: The President sat at the head of the table.

senses.definition: the position at the front of a line of people

examples.x: The prince rode at the head of his regiment.

senses.definition: the mass of leaves or flowers at the end of a stem

examples.x: Remove the dead heads to encourage new growth.

senses.definition: the mass of small bubbles on the top of a glass of beer
the part of a spot on your skin that contains a thick yellow liquid (= pus)
the component of a sound or video recording system that converts data on the disk or tape into digital electronic data (and the other way round)
used to say how many animals of a particular type are on a farm, in a herd, etc.

examples.x: 200 head of sheep

senses.definition: oral sex (= using the mouth to give somebody sexual pleasure)

examples.x: to give head

senses.definition: the central part of a phrase, which has the same grammatical function as the whole phrase. In the phrase ‘the tall man in a suit’, man is the head.
an argument
in the most important ways, without considering things that are less important

examples.x: I think we are basically saying the same thing.
There have been some problems but basically it's a good system.

senses.definition: used when you are giving your opinion or stating what is important about a situation

examples.x: Basically, there's not a lot we can do about it.

senses.definition: a competition, an argument or a struggle between people or groups of people trying to win power or control campaign

a battle of wills (= when each side is very determined to win)

senses.definition: a determined effort that somebody makes to solve a difficult problem or succeed in a difficult situation

senses.definition: a situation in which people are opposed to each other; a subject that people feel strongly about and argue about

examples.x: Arkansas is among the key electoral battlegrounds.

senses.definition: a place where a battle is being fought or has been fought
to say or write something in the form of a question, in order to get information ask

examples.x: How old are you—if you don’t mind me/my asking?

Can I ask a question?
Did you ask the price?
You do what I tell you to, no questions asked.

I often get asked that!

I'd like to ask you a few questions.
Why does everyone keep asking me that?

He asked where I lived.
I had to ask the teacher what to do next.

senses.definition: to tell somebody that you would like them to do something or that you would like something to happen

examples.x: Anyone with information is asked to contact the police.

senses.definition: to say that you would like somebody to give you something

senses.definition: to request permission to do something

examples.x: I immediately asked to speak to a supervisor.

senses.definition: to invite somebody

examples.x: They've asked me to dinner.

senses.definition: to request a particular amount of money for something that you are selling

examples.x: He's asking £2 000 for the car.

senses.definition: to expect or demand something demand

examples.x: I know I'm asking a great deal.

senses.definition: a passage in the neck through which food and air pass on their way into the body; the front part of the neck

examples.x: A sob caught in his throat.

senses.definition: having the colour of throat mentioned; making a sound in the throat of the type mentioned throat

examples.x: a blue-throated macaw

senses.definition: the degree to which something is likely to happen

senses.definition: something that makes it seem impossible to do or achieve something

senses.definition: the connection between two numbers that shows how much money somebody will receive if they win a bet

senses.definition: an exact point in time

senses.definition: a particular time in somebody's life, or in the course of an event or the development of something

senses.definition: the smaller part of a group; less than half of the people or things in a large group

senses.definition: a small group within a community or country that is different because of race, religion, language, etc. fight for/​struggle for/​promote

examples.x: the rights of ethnic/racial minorities

persecuted/oppressed minorities
minority languages
minority neighborhoods (= where no or few white people live)

senses.definition: the state of being under the age at which you are legally an adult

senses.definition: a series of musical notes that are sung or played in a particular order to form a piece of music listen to/​enjoy/​love/​be into

a football song sung to the tune of (= using the tune of) ‘When the saints go marching in’

senses.definition: to repeat an idea, argument, etc. many times to emphasize it, especially when it has already been mentioned or understood

senses.definition: a strong feeling that something/somebody exists or is true; confidence that something/somebody is good or right

senses.definition: to have a religious faith

senses.definition: a judgement about the levels or quantity of something

senses.definition: to form an opinion of the amount, value or quality of something after thinking about it carefully

senses.definition: the act of forming an opinion of the amount, value or quality of something after thinking about it carefully

senses.definition: forming or giving an opinion of the amount, value or quality of something after thinking about it carefully

examples.x: We need to make some evaluative judgements of this relationship.

senses.definition: of or belonging to a Christian group that emphasizes the authority of the Bible and the importance of people being saved through faith

examples.x: They're evangelical Christians.

senses.definition: wanting very much to persuade people to accept your views and opinions

examples.x: He delivered his speech with evangelical fervour.

senses.definition: the strong belief of some Christian groups in the authority of the Bible and the importance of people being saved through faith

examples.x: At school she became a convert to evangelicalism.

senses.definition: actions or words that you use to try to persuade people to accept views or opinions that you strongly believe are correct

examples.x: Researchers have found clear scientific evidence of a link between exposure to sun and skin cancer.

examples.x: Have you any evidence to support this allegation?

senses.definition: the information that is used in court to try to prove something break/​violate/​obey/​uphold

circumstantial/forensic evidence

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something is correct in every way or in every detail

senses.definition: used to ask for more information about something

senses.definition: used as a reply, agreeing with what somebody has just said, or emphasizing that it is correct

to sit an examination in mathematics

senses.definition: the act of looking at or considering something very carefully

senses.definition: to ask somebody questions formally, especially in court

senses.definition: the process of changing an amount of one currency for an equal value of another

examples.x: currency exchange facilities

examples.x: Our school does an exchange with a school in France.

senses.definition: a conversation or an argument

senses.definition: a building where business people met in the past to buy and sell a particular type of goods

examples.x: the old Corn Exchange

senses.definition: a place where phone calls are connected so that people can speak to each other

examples.x: Please excuse the mess.

examples.x: Nothing can excuse such rudeness.

senses.definition: to allow somebody to leave; to say in a polite way that you are leaving

senses.definition: to allow somebody to not do something that they should normally do

senses.definition: a person who supports an idea, theory, etc. and persuades others that it is good

senses.definition: a person who is able to perform a particular activity with skill

senses.definition: a raised figure or symbol that shows how many times a quantity must be multiplied by itself, for example the figure 4 in a4
to argue, disagree or protest about something
the act of arguing, disagreeing or protesting about something; a remark or statement in which somebody argues, disagrees or protests about something

senses.definition: to represent something in a particular way, for example by symbols

senses.definition: an argument or a fight

senses.definition: the way of starting play in a game of ice hockey
to start a game such as ice hockey

examples.x: Both teams are ready to face off.

senses.definition: to argue, fight or compete with somebody, or to get ready to do this

senses.definition: a small group of people within a larger one, whose members have some different aims and beliefs to those of the larger group

senses.definition: opposition, disagreement, etc. that exists between small groups of people within an organization or political party

senses.definition: films, books, etc. that combine fact with fiction (= imaginary events)

examples.x: Dave and I had a falling-out.

senses.definition: to agree to something

senses.definition: to meet a person or group by chance and then become involved with them

senses.definition: to become loose and drop

senses.definition: if soldiers fall out, they leave their lines and move away fall out

senses.definition: to be able to recognize somebody/something identify

senses.definition: to understand the difference between one person or thing and another

examples.x: I hope we have taught our children to know right from wrong.

senses.definition: to have seen, heard or experienced something

examples.x: I’ve never known it (to) snow in July before.

senses.definition: to have personal experience of something

examples.x: He has known both poverty and wealth.

examples.x: Her father is seriously ill in St Luke's hospital.
critically/gravely/severely ill

chronically ill patients (= who are ill for a long time )

senses.definition: bad or harmful

examples.x: She suffered no ill effects from the experience.

senses.definition: that brings, or is thought to bring, bad luck

examples.x: a bird of ill omen

senses.definition: in my humble opinion (used especially in emails, in text messages, on social media, etc. when you give your opinion about something)

examples.x: IMHO this film is a classic.

senses.definition: in my opinion (used especially in emails, in text messages, on social media, etc. when you give your opinion about something)

examples.x: It's a nice performance, not among his best, IMO.

senses.definition: a clever or funny copy of the way a person acts or speaks

senses.definition: an appearance that may be false

senses.definition: a mark that is left when an object is pressed hard into a surface

senses.definition: all the copies of a book that are printed at one time, with few or no changes to the contents since the last time the book was printed

senses.definition: to repeat words, phrases, etc.

senses.definition: to give particular information or instructions

senses.definition: a formal agreement between two organizations, countries, etc. concord

senses.definition: the quality of being honest

senses.definition: sloping; at an angle
behaviour or actions that follow the accepted rules of society

senses.definition: not matching a set of standards, ideas, etc.

senses.definition: in a way that does not match a set of standards, ideas, etc.

senses.definition: in a way that changes too often and does not stay the same

senses.definition: that is true and cannot be disagreed with or denied

senses.definition: in a way that cannot be disagreed with or denied

senses.definition: in a way that cannot be disagreed with or denied

senses.definition: in a way that cannot be disagreed with or denied

senses.definition: unwilling to change their opinions, decisions, etc., or the way they do things

senses.definition: difficult or impossible to bend
in a way that cannot be changed or made more suitable for a particular situation

senses.definition: a person who is equal to somebody else in strength, skill, intelligence, etc.

senses.definition: a person or thing that combines well with somebody/something else

senses.definition: to provide something that is suitable for or enough for a particular situation

senses.definition: a person who does not behave or think like everyone else, but who has independent, unusual opinions

senses.definition: used when you are not certain that something will happen or that something is true or is a correct number

senses.definition: used when making a suggestion

examples.x: I thought maybe we could go together.

senses.definition: to form a wrong opinion about a person or situation, especially in a way that makes you deal with them or it unfairly

senses.definition: to estimate something such as time or distance wrongly

examples.x: The government made a serious misjudgment in its reaction to the crisis.

senses.definition: the act of estimating something such as time or distance wrongly

examples.x: I ran out of wool thanks to a silly misjudgement.

examples.cf: it is a mistake to do something

senses.definition: a person who has opinions, especially about politics, that are not extreme modest

a person who is caught between two people or groups who are fighting or arguing

senses.definition: to shape a soft substance into a particular form or object by pressing it or by putting it into a mould

examples.x: First, mould the clay into the desired shape.

examples.x: The experience had moulded and coloured her whole life.

senses.definition: the fact of somebody paying attention to somebody/something or knowing about something

examples.x: Don't take any notice of what you read in the papers.

senses.definition: information or a warning given in advance of something that is going to happen

senses.definition: a formal letter or statement saying that you will or must leave your job or house at the end of a particular period of time

examples.x: He has handed in his notice.

500 workers have been issued with redundancy notices.

senses.definition: a short article in a newspaper or magazine, giving an opinion about a book, play, etc.

senses.definition: very probably likely

examples.x: As likely as not she's forgotten all about it.

senses.definition: to give something as a reason for opposing something

senses.definition: not influenced by personal feelings or opinions; considering only facts

examples.x: an objective assessment of the situation
objective truth/facts/reality

senses.definition: existing outside the mind; based on facts that can be proved

examples.x: objective reality

senses.definition: the objective case is the one which is used for the object of a sentence objective
the fact of not being influenced by personal feelings or opinions but considering only facts

examples.x: There was a lack of objectivity in the way the candidates were judged.

senses.definition: the fact of something being based only on facts that can be proved

examples.x: a high standard of scientific objectivity

senses.definition: belonging to somebody; relating to somebody of

examples.x: a friend of mine
the love of a mother for her child
the role of the teacher

the paintings of Monet

senses.definition: belonging to something; being part of something; relating to something

examples.x: the lid of the box
the director of the company
a member of the team
the result of the debate

senses.definition: coming from a particular background or living in a place

examples.x: a woman of Italian descent
the people of Wales

senses.definition: relating to or showing somebody/something

examples.x: a story of passion
a photo of my dog
a map of India

senses.definition: used to say what somebody/something is, consists of or contains

examples.x: the city of Dublin
the issue of housing

a glass of milk

senses.definition: used with measurements and expressions of time, age, etc.

a girl of 12

senses.definition: used to show somebody/something belongs to a group, often after some, a few, etc.

senses.definition: used to show the position of something/somebody in space or time

criticism of the police (= they are criticized)

the howling of the wind

senses.definition: used after some verbs before mentioning somebody/something involved in the action

senses.definition: used after some adjectives before mentioning somebody/something that a feeling relates to

senses.definition: used to give your opinion of somebody’s behaviour

senses.definition: used when one noun describes a second one

senses.definition: a large area of land that is designed for playing golf on

senses.definition: any of the separate parts of a meal eat (lunch/​dinner)/dine/​meet

examples.x: The president appears likely to change course on some key issues.

senses.definition: the direction a river moves in

senses.definition: a series of medical treatments, tablets, etc.

senses.definition: a continuous layer of brick, stone or other building material in a wall

senses.definition: yes; all right

examples.x: ‘Shall we go for a walk?’ ‘OK.’

senses.definition: used to attract somebody’s attention or to introduce a comment

examples.x: Okay, let's go.

senses.definition: used to check that somebody agrees with you or understands you

examples.x: The meeting's at 2, OK?

senses.definition: used to stop people arguing with you or criticizing you

examples.x: OK, so I was wrong. I'm sorry.

senses.definition: to officially agree to something or allow it to happen

examples.x: She filled in an expenses claim and her manager OK'd it.

senses.definition: used to express agreement
something that you think of or remember

examples.x: I couldn't bear the thought of waiting any longer.
The very thought of it makes me feel sick.
I don't like the thought of you walking home alone.

senses.definition: a person’s mind and all the ideas that they have in it when they are thinking

examples.x: This is the time of year when our thoughts turn to summer holidays.

senses.definition: the act of thinking seriously and carefully about something

examples.x: I've given the matter careful thought.

senses.definition: the power or process of thinking

examples.x: A good teacher encourages independence of thought.

senses.definition: a feeling of care or worry

examples.x: Spare a thought for those without enough to eat this winter.

senses.definition: an intention or a hope of doing something

senses.definition: an expression that is shown on somebody’s face beam

senses.definition: used to refer to a person of the type mentioned

senses.definition: having the type of face or expression mentioned

examples.x: pale-faced
a freckle-faced boy
grim-faced
a sad-faced woman

senses.definition: a side or surface of something

senses.definition: the front part of a clock or watch

senses.definition: the state of being as different as possible; two things that are as different as possible

senses.definition: strongly disagreeing with somebody/something

senses.definition: using the hand or number of hands mentioned

senses.definition: a part of a clock or watch that points to the numbers

senses.definition: a sailor on a ship

examples.x: All hands on deck!

senses.definition: by a person rather than a machine

senses.definition: no longer continuing or working in the normal way

senses.definition: a political organization that you can vote for in elections and whose members have the same aims and ideas create/​form/​be the leader of

examples.x: Do you belong to a political party?
the ruling/opposition party

the party leader/conference
a party member/activist/official

senses.definition: a group of people who are doing something together such as travelling or visiting somewhere

senses.definition: the ability to understand the true nature of something

senses.definition: possibly

senses.definition: in a way that is connected with one particular person rather than a group of people

senses.definition: in a way that is intended to be offensive

senses.definition: to choose somebody/something from a group of people or things choose

senses.definition: a type of shoe with a high, thick sole; the sole on such a shoe

senses.definition: the open part at the back of a double-decker bus where you get on or off

examples.x: I decided to play along with her idea.

senses.definition: a playing card with a large single symbol on it, which has either the highest or the lowest value in a particular card game

senses.definition: a serve (= the first hit) that is so good that your opponent cannot reach the ball

senses.definition: complete and definite

senses.definition: to state your opinion on something, or give a decision about something

senses.definition: a standard used to measure the strength of alcoholic drinks
an idea or a plan of action that is suggested, especially in business

senses.definition: to be present in something to a particular degree

examples.x: Women and men were represented equally on the teams.
Women are disproportionately represented among welfare recipients.

senses.definition: to be an example or expression of something

examples.x: The project represents all that is good in the community.
Those comments do not represent the views of us all.
The book purported to represent the lives of ordinary people.

senses.definition: to show somebody/something, especially in a picture

examples.x: The carvings represent a hunting scene.
The map represents Italy in the 12th century.
The results are represented in fig. 3 below.
The Egyptian goddess is represented as a woman with cow's horns.

senses.definition: to present or describe somebody/something in a particular way, especially when this may not be fair

examples.x: The king is represented as a villain in the play.
The risks were represented as negligible.
The film represents us as helpless victims.
The film accurately represents the atmosphere of the post-war period.

senses.definition: to make a formal statement to somebody in authority to make your opinions known or to protest

examples.x: They represented their concerns to the authorities.
He admitted falsely representing to police officers that the car had been stolen.

senses.definition: the act of presenting somebody/something in a particular way; something that shows or describes something

examples.x: the negative representation of single mothers in the media
The snake swallowing its tail is a representation of infinity.

senses.definition: the fact of having representatives who will speak or vote for you or act in your place

examples.x: The green movement lacks effective representation in Parliament.
The accused was not allowed legal representation.

senses.definition: formal statements made to somebody in authority, especially in order to make your opinions known or to protest

examples.x: We have made representations to the prime minister, but without success.

senses.definition: the opinion that people have about what somebody/something is like, based on what has happened in the past

examples.x: to have a good/bad reputation
to build/earn a reputation
She soon established a reputation as a first-class cook.
The company enjoys an international reputation for quality of design.
a politician with a reputation for honesty
I'm aware of Mark's reputation for being late.
He has the reputation of being a hard worker.
to damage/tarnish/ruin somebody’s reputation
The weather in England is living up to its reputation (= is exactly as expected).
She is, by reputation, very difficult to please.

senses.definition: the opinion that people have of somebody/something

examples.x: I know him only by repute.
She is a writer of international repute.
My parents were artists of (some) repute (= having a very good reputation).

senses.definition: generally thought to be something or to have done something, although this is not certain

examples.x: He is reputed to be the best heart surgeon in the country.
The house is wrongly reputed to have been the poet's birthplace.
She sold her share of the company for a reputed £7 million.

senses.definition: used to say that something is generally thought to be true, although this is not certain

examples.x: He was reputedly a millionaire.
It is reputedly the best hotel in the country.

senses.definition: a supply of something that is available to be used in the future or when it is needed

examples.x: cash/foreign currency reserves
large oil and gas reserves
reserve funds
He discovered unexpected reserves of strength.
The country has the world's largest reserves of coal.
The company has substantial reserves of capital.

senses.definition: a piece of land that is a protected area for animals, plants, etc.

examples.x: a wildlife/forest reserve

senses.definition: an area of land in the US that is kept separate for native North Americans to live in
the quality that somebody has when they do not talk easily to other people about their ideas, feelings, etc.

examples.x: She found it difficult to make friends because of her natural reserve.
Jaime always talked to people without reserve.

senses.definition: a feeling that you do not want to accept or agree to something, etc. until you are quite sure that it is all right to do so

examples.x: Any contract should be treated with reserve until it has been checked.
She trusted him without reserve (= completely).

senses.definition: an extra player who plays in a team when one of the other players is injured or not available to play
a team that is below the level of the main team
an extra military force, etc. that is not part of a country’s regular forces, but is available to be used when needed

examples.x: the Army Reserve
the reserve police

senses.definition: the lowest price that somebody will accept for something, especially something that is sold at an auction

examples.x: The painting failed to reach to its reserve and was withdrawn from the sale.

senses.definition: slow or unwilling to show feelings or express opinions

examples.x: Neighbours described him as a reserved man who didn't mix much.
She seems quite reserved.

senses.definition: a definite decision to do or not to do something

examples.x: Have you made any New Year's resolutions (= for example, to give up smoking from 1 January)?
She made a resolution to visit her relatives more often.

senses.definition: a formal statement of an opinion agreed on by a committee or a council, especially by means of a vote

examples.x: to pass/adopt/approve a resolution
The UN Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution calling for a halt to hostilities.

senses.definition: the act of solving or settling a problem, argument, etc.

examples.x: dispute/conflict resolution
The government is pressing for an early resolution of the dispute.
Hopes of a peaceful resolution to the conflict were fading.

senses.definition: the quality of being resolute or determined

examples.x: The reforms owe a great deal to the resolution of one man.
Her resolution never faltered.
She showed great resolution in her dealings with management.

senses.definition: the power of a computer screen, printer, etc. to give a clear image, depending on the size of the dots (= marks) that make up the image

examples.x: The graphics look fine, even at low resolution.
The higher the resolution, the sharper the image.
a monitor capable of a 1 024 by 768 pixel resolution

senses.definition: to have a very good opinion of somebody/something; to admire somebody/something

examples.x: I respect Jack's opinion on most subjects.
She was a much loved and highly respected teacher.
She had always been honest with me, and I respect her for that.

senses.definition: to be careful about something; to make sure you do not do something that might be considered wrong

examples.x: Employers must respect employees' privacy.
to respect other people’s property
I respect your right to disagree.
She promised to respect our wishes.

senses.definition: to agree not to break a law, principle, etc.

examples.x: The new leader has promised to respect the constitution.
The government has promised to respect human rights.

senses.definition: a report in a newspaper or magazine, or on the internet, television or radio, in which somebody gives their opinion of a book, play, film, product, etc.; the act of writing this kind of report write/​publish

examples.x: a book review
She gave the film a glowing review.
mixed/negative/bad reviews
a positive/favourable review
an online review of the restaurant
He submitted his latest novel for review.

senses.definition: an act of looking again at something you have studied or written, especially in order to prepare for an exam

examples.x: We need to do the review for the test tomorrow.
I should have time for a quick review of my notes before the test.
We'll have time at the end of class for review.
There is a grammar review section at the end of each unit.

senses.definition: an examination of something, with the intention of changing it if necessary

examples.x: The government has embarked on a systematic review of transport policy.
MPS have called for an independent review.
The proposals are available for review online.
The terms of the contract are under review.
His parole application is up for review next week.
a review board/panel
a pay/salary review

senses.definition: an examination of all the relevant information on a subject or on a series of events

examples.x: to conduct/undertake a review of customer complaints
to publish a review of recent cancer research
a comprehensive review of current scientific knowledge on the subject
a thorough review of relevant materials
The literature review suggests a number of areas for further study.

senses.definition: a ceremony that involves an official inspection of soldiers, etc. by an important visitor
to write a report of a book, play, film, product, etc. in which you give your opinion of it

examples.x: Please rate and review your purchase on our website.
The play was reviewed in the national newspapers.
The book was favourably reviewed by most critics.

senses.definition: to look again at something you have studied, especially in order to prepare for an exam

examples.x: We will be reviewing all the topics covered this semester.
Jonas helped me review for the test.

senses.definition: to check a piece of work to see if there are any mistakes

examples.x: Review your work before you turn it in.

senses.definition: to carefully examine or consider something again, especially so that you can decide if it is necessary to make changes examine

examples.x: The government will review the situation later in the year.
The company is reviewing its business travel policy.
After reviewing the evidence, the judge dismissed the case.
This case should be reviewed in the light of new evidence.
to review a decision/proposal
Staff performance is reviewed annually.

senses.definition: to read or study information about something, especially in order to reach an opinion about it

examples.x: to review records/documents/data
Let's start by reviewing the evidence.
This paper reviews the literature on the subject.
The next section briefly reviews previous studies.
Students can review the material at their own pace.
You should review the document carefully before signing.

senses.definition: to think about past events, for example to try to understand why they happened

examples.x: to review your failures and triumphs
She had been reviewing the previous week on her way home.

senses.definition: to make an official inspection of a group of soldiers, etc. in a military ceremony

examples.x: The Commander-in-Chief reviewed the troops.

senses.definition: a person who writes reviews of books, films or plays

examples.x: a book reviewer for ‘The Guardian’
The movie was enthusiastically received by the reviewers.

senses.definition: a person who examines or considers something carefully, for example to see if any changes need to be made
to change your opinions or plans, for example because of something you have learned

examples.x: I can see I will have to revise my opinions of his abilities now.
The government may need to revise its policy in the light of this report.
I realised that I would have to revise my life plan.

senses.definition: to change something, such as a book or an estimate, in order to correct or improve it

examples.x: a revised edition of a textbook
I'll prepare a revised estimate for you.
This revised version of his play has only two acts.
They should create a revised marketing plan.
We may have to revise this figure upwards.
The growth forecast has been revised down.
Of the original 200, that was revised to 100, only about 50 people showed up.

senses.definition: to prepare for an exam by looking again at work that you have done

examples.x: I can't come out tonight. I have to revise.
I spent the weekend revising for my exam.
I'm revising Geography today.

senses.definition: a serious break in the relationship between people or organizations facilitate/​regulate

examples.x: The rift within the party deepened.
Efforts to heal the rift between the two countries have failed.

senses.definition: a large break or opening in the ground, rocks or clouds

examples.x: Through a rift in the clouds we could see a beautiful blue sky.
The volcano was in a remote area of the northern rift, accessible only by helicopter.

senses.definition: true or correct as a fact true

examples.x: Did you get the answer right?
‘What's the right time?’ ‘10.37.’
That's exactly right.
‘David, isn't it?’ ‘Yes, that's right.’
It was Monday you went to see Angie, right?
Let me get this right (= understand correctly)—you want us to do an extra ten hours' work for no extra pay?

senses.definition: correct in your opinion or judgement

examples.x: You were quite right about the weather.
They're absolutely right to be cautious.
‘It's not easy.’ ‘Yeah, you're right.’
Am I right in thinking we've met before?
History has proved him right.
He never gets anything right.

senses.definition: correct for a particular situation or thing, or for a particular person right

examples.x: Have you got the right money (= the exact amount) for the bus fare?
What's the right way to do this?
You're not holding it the right way up.
Are you sure you've got that on the right way round?
This is a step in the right direction.
Next time we'll get it right.
She's definitely the right person for the job.
I'm glad you split up. She wasn't right for you.
I was waiting for the right moment to ask him.
I think we made the right decision.

senses.definition: morally good or acceptable; correct according to law or a person’s duty

examples.x: I hope we're doing the right thing.
I don't know, it just doesn't seem right.
On some level this just feels right.
You were quite right to criticize him.
It's only right to warn you of the risk.
It's right that he should be punished.

senses.definition: in a normal or good enough condition

examples.x: I don't feel quite right today (= I feel ill).
Things aren't right between her parents.
If only I could have helped put matters right.
That sausage doesn't smell right.
The meat doesn't taste right to me.

senses.definition: socially fashionable or important

examples.x: She knows all the right people (= for example, people who can help her in her career).
They make sure that their children go to the right schools.
I wore the best clothes and was seen in all the right places.

senses.definition: of, on or towards the side of the body that is towards the east when a person faces north

examples.x: your right hand/arm/foot/leg
My right eye is weaker than my left eye.
Keep on the right side of the road.
Take a right turn at the intersection.

senses.definition: used to emphasize something bad

examples.x: You made a right mess of that!
I felt a right idiot.

senses.definition: used to show that you accept a statement or an order

examples.x: ‘You may find it hurts a little at first.’ ‘Right.’
‘Barry's here.’ ‘Oh, right.’
‘I'll have a whisky and soda.’ ‘Right you are, sir.’

senses.definition: used to get somebody’s attention to say that you are ready to do something, or to tell them to do something

examples.x: Right! Let's get going.

senses.definition: used to check that somebody agrees with you or has understood you

examples.x: So that's twenty of each sort, right?
And I didn't think any more of it, right, but Mum says I should see a doctor.

senses.definition: used to say that you do not believe somebody or that you disagree with them

examples.x: ‘I won't be late tonight.’ ‘Yeah, right.’

senses.definition: having beliefs and opinions that most people approve of

examples.x: Any right-minded person would be offended by this book.

senses.definition: having political opinions or being aware of social issues that are fashionable and left-wing

examples.x: right-on middle-class intellectuals

senses.definition: having beliefs and opinions that most people approve of
divided because of disagreements, especially in a violent way

examples.x: a party riven by internal disputes

senses.definition: divided into two or more pieces

examples.x: The wood was riven with deep cracks.

senses.definition: a serious argument between people, organizations, etc. about something

examples.x: A row has broken out over education.

senses.definition: a noisy argument between two or more people rouse

examples.x: She left him after a blazing row.
family rows
He had a row with his son.
Carol and I had a terrible row about how much money she spends.

senses.definition: a loud unpleasant noise

examples.x: Who's making that row?

senses.definition: to have a noisy argument

examples.x: Mike and Sue are always rowing.
She had rowed with her parents about her boyfriend.

senses.definition: to change an earlier statement, opinion or promise

examples.x: Today he seemed to be rowing back from what he said last night.
The government is now trying to row back on its commitments.

senses.definition: the act of changing an earlier decision or opinion completely so that it is the opposite of what it was before

examples.x: The government was forced into more rowbacks on budget cuts.

senses.definition: a situation in which there is a lot of noise, activity and argument rumpus

examples.x: She went outside to see who was causing such a ruckus.

senses.definition: angry protests or arguments

examples.x: There'll be ructions if her father ever finds out.
The announcement caused serious ructions.

senses.definition: an argument or a fight

examples.x: The fiery player has had numerous run-ins with referees.

senses.definition: a period of time leading up to an important event; the preparation for this
to speak or tell somebody something, using words said

examples.x: ‘Hello!’ she said.
‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.
A legendary football coach once said, ‘Winning is everything.’

senses.definition: to repeat words, phrases, etc.

examples.x: to say a prayer
Try to say that line with more conviction.

senses.definition: to give particular information or instructions

examples.x: The notice said ‘Keep Out’.
The clock said three o'clock.
The instructions say (that) we should leave it to set for four hours.
The book doesn't say where he was born.
The guidebook says to turn left.

senses.definition: to express an opinion on something

examples.x: Say what you like (= although you disagree) about her, she's a fine singer.
I'll say this for them, they're a very efficient company.
Anna thinks I'm lazy—what do you say (= what is your opinion)?
I can't say I blame her for resigning (= I think she was right).
I have to say I enjoyed every minute.
I say (= suggest) we go without them.
I wouldn't say they were rich (= in my opinion they are not rich).
That's not to say it's a bad movie (= it is good but it is not without faults).
It's hard to say what caused the accident.
It's difficult to say whether the story is true.
‘When will it be finished?’ ‘I couldn't say (= I don't know).’
Is it worth it? I would say not.

senses.definition: to make thoughts, feelings, etc. clear to somebody by using words, looks, movements, etc.

examples.x: His angry glance said it all.
Just what is the artist trying to say in her work?
The museum's architects have managed to say something about our national story.

senses.definition: to show, sometimes indirectly, what somebody/something is like

examples.x: That says it all really, doesn't it? (= it shows clearly what is true)
The incident says an awful lot about his character.
This says to me that there is more here than you are letting on.

senses.definition: to suggest or give something as an example or a possibility

examples.x: You could learn the basics in, let's say, three months.
Let’s take any writer, say (= for example) Dickens…
Say you lose your job: what would you do then?
Just say he refuses to talk to you.

senses.definition: the right to influence something by giving your opinion before a decision is made

examples.x: We had no say in the decision to sell the company.
People want a greater say in local government.
The judge has the final say on the sentence.

senses.definition: the place where something happens, especially something unpleasant scene

examples.x: the scene of the accident/crime/crash
The attacker fled the scene.
Italy was the scene of many demonstrations at that time.
Firefighters arrived on the scene within minutes.
Sadly the man died at the scene.

senses.definition: an event or a situation that you see, especially one of a particular type

examples.x: The team's victory produced scenes of jubilation all over the country.
a scene of devastation/carnage
She witnessed some very distressing scenes.

senses.definition: a part of a film, play or book in which the action happens in one place or is of one particular type

examples.x: sex/fight/action/battle scenes
deleted scenes (= ones that were not included in the final version)
to film/shoot a scene
They shot the opening scene 15 times.
I got very nervous before my big scene (= the one where I have a very important part).
The scene where he arrives at the factory is the turning point in the book.

senses.definition: one of the small sections that a play or an opera is divided into

examples.x: Act I, Scene 2 of ‘Macbeth’

senses.definition: a particular area of activity or way of life and the people who are part of it

examples.x: the art/club/punk scene
a newcomer on the music scene
British players were finding it increasingly difficult to compete on the international scene.
Tarantino burst onto the cinema scene in the ’90s.
After years at the top, she just vanished from the scene.

senses.definition: a view that you see view

examples.x: a delightful rural scene
They went abroad for a change of scene (= to see and experience new surroundings).
We stood and surveyed the scene.
I stared out of the window of the train on the ever-changing scene.

senses.definition: a painting, drawing, or photograph of a place and the things that are happening there

examples.x: an exhibition of Parisian street scenes
He painted scenes of country life.

senses.definition: a loud, angry argument, especially one that happens in public and is embarrassing

examples.x: She had made a scene in the middle of the party.
‘Please leave,’ he said. ‘I don't want a scene.’

senses.definition: to make secret plans to do something that will help yourself and possibly harm others

examples.x: She seemed to feel that we were all scheming against her.
His colleagues, meanwhile, were busily scheming to get rid of him.
Her enemies were scheming her downfall.

senses.definition: to think or form an opinion about something

examples.x: What do you scheme?
‘Do you think he'll come?’ ‘I scheme so.’

senses.definition: strong disagreement within an organization, especially a religious one, that makes its members divide into separate groups

examples.x: The disagreement eventually led to a schism within the Church.
the growing schism between the leadership and the ordinary party members
By 1914 the party was dangerously close to schism.

senses.definition: affected by or relating to schizophrenia
frequently changing your mind about something or holding opinions about something that seem to oppose each other

examples.x: The American public is remarkably schizophrenic in its attitude to the gun.

senses.definition: to win points, goals, etc. in a game or competition

examples.x: Fraser scored again in the second half.
to score a goal/try/touchdown/victory/point/run
Brazil failed to score a win, leaving their further progress in the competition in doubt.
the only man to score a hat-trick in a World Cup final
On his debut at Old Trafford he scored 154 against Australia.
She scored 20 points in 36 minutes.
He scored 30 goals in 20 games.

senses.definition: to keep a record of the points, goals, etc. won in a game or competition

examples.x: Who's going to score?

senses.definition: to gain marks in a test or an exam

examples.x: She scored 98 per cent in the French test.
Girls usually score highly in language exams.
Women consistently scored higher than men in this test.
Some studies show that low-income Latino adolescents tend to score low on self-esteem.

senses.definition: to give something/somebody a particular number of points

examples.x: The tests are scored by psychologists.
Score each criterion on a scale of 1 to 5.
a scoring system

senses.definition: to be worth a particular number of points

examples.x: Each correct answer will score two points.

senses.definition: to succeed; to have an advantage

examples.x: The army continued to score successes in the south.
Lewis scored a win with a hugely funny sketch about a car salesman.
She's scored again with her latest blockbuster.
Bicycles score over other forms of transport in towns.

senses.definition: to arrange a piece of music for one or more musical instruments or for voices

examples.x: The piece is scored for violin, viola and cello.
The director invited him to score the movie (= write the music for it).

senses.definition: to make a cut or mark on a surface

examples.x: Score the card first with a knife.

senses.definition: to have sex with a new partner

examples.x: Did you score last night?

senses.definition: to buy or get illegal drugs
to show that you are better than somebody, especially by making clever remarks, for example in an argument

examples.x: He was always trying to score off his teachers.

senses.definition: a strong feeling that somebody/something is stupid or not good enough, usually shown by the way you speak

examples.x: Her fellow teachers greeted her proposal with scorn.
She was unable to hide the scorn in her voice.
They had nothing but scorn for his political views.

senses.definition: to feel or show that you think somebody/something is stupid and you do not respect them or it

examples.x: She scorned their views as old-fashioned.
Such methods are scorned by reputable practitioners.
His brother had always scorned him.

senses.definition: to refuse to have or do something because you are too proud

examples.x: to scorn an invitation
She would have scorned to stoop to such tactics.

senses.definition: a small piece of something, especially paper, cloth, etc.

examples.x: She scribbled his phone number on a scrap of paper.
scraps of information
She was just a scrap of a thing (= small and thin).
Some of the women were wearing scraps of cloth in their hair.

senses.definition: a small amount of something

examples.x: It won't make a scrap of difference.
There's not a scrap of evidence to support his claim.
a barren landscape without a scrap of vegetation
He ate every last scrap of the food.

senses.definition: food left after a meal

examples.x: Give the scraps to the dog.

senses.definition: things that are not wanted or cannot be used for their original purpose, but which have some value for the material they are made of

examples.x: We sold the car for scrap (= so that any good parts can be used again).
scrap metal
a scrap dealer (= a person who buys and sells scrap)

senses.definition: a short fight or argument

examples.x: He was always getting into scraps at school.

senses.definition: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes seas

examples.x: She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.
I looked out of the window but saw nothing.
The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).
I would like to see some proof of this statement.
The divers reported seeing a lot of sharks.
He recalls seeing his father sitting at the kitchen table.
I've never seen anything like this!
He could see (that) she had been crying.
Did you see what happened?
If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.
I hate to see you unhappy.
She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.
I saw you put the key in your pocket.

examples.cf: somebody/something is seen to do something
examples.x: He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.
The government not only has to do something, it must be seen to be doing something (= people must be aware that it is doing something).
The walls were too high to see over.

senses.definition: to have or use the power of sight

examples.x: She will never see again (= she has become blind).
On a clear day you can see for miles from here.
It was getting dark and I couldn't see to read.
I could hardly see because of the smoke.

senses.definition: to watch a game, television programme, performance, etc. look

examples.x: Did you see that programme on Brazil last night?
In the evening we went to see a movie.
Fifty thousand people saw the match.
I finally got to see them in concert.
I really want to see this film now.
This performance was very beautiful, like nothing I had ever seen before.
I remember seeing that movie when I was a kid.
It's not the sort of thing you see on TV that often.
This film really deserves to be seen on a big screen.

senses.definition: to look at something in order to find information; to go to somebody in order to ask for help or information

examples.x: See page 158.
If you missed the session, see a member of staff for advice.
See Table 2 for details.
See also paragraphs 6.5 to 6.9 above.
See above/below for a breakdown of the costs.
See over (= the next page) for details.

senses.definition: to be near and recognize somebody; to meet somebody by chance

examples.x: Guess who I saw at the party last night!
Aren't you pleased to see me?
It's so good to see you!

senses.definition: to visit somebody/something

examples.x: Come and see us again soon.
Around 200  000 visitors each year come to see the summer palace.

senses.definition: to have a meeting with somebody

examples.x: You ought to see a doctor about that cough.
What is it you want to see me about?
I can only see you for five minutes.

senses.definition: to spend time with somebody

examples.x: Are you seeing anyone (= having a romantic relationship with anyone)?
They've been seeing a lot of each other (= spending a lot of time together) recently.
We haven't seen much of Liz lately.
He has changed since his family last saw him.

senses.definition: to understand something understand

examples.x: ‘It opens like this.’ ‘Oh, I see.’
He didn't see the joke.
I don't think she saw the point of the story.
He changed the way we see the world around us.
to see a/the need for something
I see no need to involve the law.
I can see both sides of the argument.
They saw nothing wrong with having three cars.
Make Lydia see reason (= be sensible), will you?
Can’t you see (that) he’s taking advantage of you?
I don't see that it matters what Josh thinks.
‘It's broken.’ ‘Oh yes, I see what you mean.’
‘Can we go swimming?’ ‘I don't see why not (= yes, you can).’
They will be able to see what really happened there.

senses.definition: to have an opinion of something regard

examples.x: I see things differently now.
Try to see things from her point of view.
The way I see it, you have three main problems.
As far as I can see (= in my opinion), you've done nothing wrong.
Lack of money is the main problem, as I see it (= in my opinion).
She is in love with him but Darren sees their relationship in a different light (= has a different opinion).

senses.definition: to consider something as a future possibility; to imagine somebody/something as something imagine

examples.x: I can't see her changing her mind.
I can't really see myself working in a lab all day.
His colleagues see him as a future director.
She was quiet and withdrawn and never saw herself as a dancer.

senses.definition: to find out something by looking, asking or waiting

examples.x: ‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll just go and see.’
‘Is he going to get better?’ ‘I don't know, we'll just have to wait and see.’
We'll have a great time, you'll see.
Go and see what the kids are doing, will you?
We'll have to see how it goes.
It will be interesting to see what happens.
I see (that) interest rates are going up again.

senses.definition: to find out or decide something by thinking or considering

examples.x: ‘Will you be able to help us?’ ‘I don't know, I'll have to see.’

senses.definition: to make sure that you do something or that something is done

senses.definition: to experience or suffer something

examples.x: He has seen a great deal in his long life.

senses.definition: to be the time when an event happens

examples.x: Next year sees the centenary of Saint-Saëns' death.

senses.definition: to be the place where an event happens

examples.x: This stadium has seen many thrilling football games.

senses.definition: to go with somebody to help or protect them

examples.x: I saw the children across (= helped them cross) the road.

senses.definition: to keep changing from one situation, opinion, emotion, etc. to another and back again saw

examples.x: Her emotions see-sawed from anger to fear.

senses.definition: the opinion or idea you have of yourself, especially of your appearance or abilities

examples.x: to have a positive/negative self-image

senses.definition: believing that your own opinions are always right and refusing to listen to those of other people
a good opinion of yourself, which is considered bad if you have too little or too much

examples.x: He suffers from a lack of self-regard.

senses.definition: having or showing too high an opinion of yourself

examples.x: His autobiography is nothing but self-regarding nonsense.

senses.definition: a feeling or an opinion, especially one based on emotions

senses.definition: a small fight or an argument

an eyeshade

senses.definition: material that covers a window, often consisting of a roll of cloth that is fixed at the top of the window and can be pulled up and down

examples.x: a dark/light/pale/bright shade of blue

senses.definition: sunglasses (= a pair of glasses with dark glass in them that you wear to protect your eyes from bright light from the sun)

examples.x: The whole house shakes when a train goes past.

examples.x: She bent down to shake a pebble out of her shoe.

examples.x: Do people in Italy shake hands when they meet?

senses.definition: to make short quick movements that you cannot control, for example because you are cold or afraid

senses.definition: to make a belief or an idea less certain

senses.definition: to get rid of something

examples.cf: shift something from somebody/something to somebody/something

senses.definition: to move quickly

senses.definition: to change your opinion of or attitude towards something, or change the way that you do something

senses.definition: to make somebody else responsible for something you should do or something bad that you have done

senses.definition: to remove something such as a dirty mark

examples.x: a detergent that shifts even the most stubborn stains

senses.definition: to sell goods, especially goods that are difficult to sell

examples.x: They cut prices drastically to try and shift stock.

senses.definition: to change the gears when you are driving a vehicle

examples.x: to shift into second gear

the fact of having fixed opinions and ways of doing things and not being willing to change them or consider other people's opinions or feelings; the fact of being interested in small problems and details and not in things which are really important

the struggle between good and evil

senses.definition: a physical fight between two people or groups of people, especially when one of them is trying to escape, or to get something from the other fight

examples.x: There were no signs of a struggle at the murder scene.

senses.definition: something that is difficult for you to do or achieve

examples.x: It was a real struggle to be ready on time.

senses.definition: determined not to change your opinion or attitude

examples.x: He was too stubborn to admit that he was wrong.
She can be as stubborn as a mule (= extremely stubborn).
stubborn pride
a stubborn resistance to change
a stubborn refusal to listen

senses.definition: difficult to get rid of or deal with

examples.x: a stubborn cough/stain
a stubborn problem

senses.definition: in a way that shows you are determined not to change your opinion or attitude

examples.x: She stubbornly refused to pay.

senses.definition: in a way that is difficult to get rid of or deal with

examples.x: Unemployment remains stubbornly high.

senses.definition: determination not to change your opinion or attitude

examples.x: I was committed to my plan out of sheer stubbornness.

senses.definition: the fact of being difficult to deal with or get rid of

examples.x: the stubbornness of the problem

senses.definition: based on your own ideas or opinions rather than facts and therefore sometimes unfair

examples.x: a highly subjective point of view

senses.definition: existing in somebody’s mind rather than in the outside world
the subjective case is the one which is used for the subject of a sentence subjective
in a way that is based on a person's own ideas, opinions or feelings rather than the facts

examples.x: People who are less subjectively involved are better judges.

senses.definition: in a way that is based on what is in somebody's mind rather than on facts that can be proved

examples.x: subjectively perceived changes

senses.definition: the fact of being influenced by personal ideas, opinions or feelings, rather than facts

examples.x: There is an element of subjectivity in her criticism.

senses.definition: the fact of existing in somebody's mind rather than the outside world

examples.x: How do we overcome the subjectivity inherent in our being?

senses.definition: to put forward an idea or a plan for other people to think about argue

examples.x: I'd like to suggest a different explanation for the company's decline.

examples.x: Who would you suggest for the job?

examples.x: All the evidence suggests (that) he stole the money.

senses.definition: to state something indirectly

examples.x: Are you suggesting (that) I’m lazy?

senses.definition: an idea or a plan that you mention for somebody else to think about

examples.x: Can I make a suggestion?

senses.definition: a reason to think that something, especially something bad, is true

examples.x: A spokesman dismissed any suggestion of a boardroom rift.

senses.definition: putting an idea into people’s minds by connecting it with other ideas

examples.x: Most advertisements work through suggestion.
the power of suggestion

senses.definition: a slight amount or sign of something

examples.x: She looked at me with just a suggestion of a smile.

senses.definition: a speech that the judge makes near the end of a trial in court, in which they remind the jury about the evidence and the most important points in the case before the jury makes its decision
an occasion when somebody states the main points of an argument, etc.
to state the main points of something in a short and clear form

examples.x: To sum up, there are three main ways of tackling the problem…
The report attempts to sum up recent economic trends.
The storyline can be summed up in a few sentences.

senses.definition: to give a summary of the main facts and arguments in a legal case, near the end of a trial
to help or encourage somebody/something by saying or showing that you agree with them/it

examples.x: to support an idea/a view
The party fully supports new welfare reform bill.
Efforts to reduce waste are strongly supported by environmental groups.

senses.definition: to give or be ready to give help to somebody if they need it

examples.x: an organization that supports people with AIDS

senses.definition: to like a particular sports team, watch their games, etc.

examples.x: Which team do you support?

senses.definition: to help or encourage something to be successful by giving it money

examples.x: The project was supported by grants from various charities.

senses.definition: to provide everything necessary, especially money, so that somebody/something can live or exist

examples.x: He struggles to support his family.

senses.definition: to help to show that something is true There is clear evidence that

examples.x: Current data support this hypothesis.
There is no evidence to support his claims.
The witness's story was not supported by the evidence.
He said the figures were questionable and not well supported.

senses.definition: to hold somebody/something in position; to prevent somebody/something from falling

examples.x: a platform supported by concrete pillars

senses.definition: to perform in a pop or rock concert before the main performer

examples.x: They were supported by a local Liverpool band.

senses.definition: to allow a particular program, language or device to be used with it

examples.x: This digital audio player supports multiple formats.

senses.definition: to think or believe that something is true or possible (based on the knowledge that you have)

examples.x: Getting a visa isn't as simple as you might suppose.

senses.definition: used to make a statement, request or suggestion less direct or less strong

examples.x: I could take you in the car, I suppose (= but I don't really want to).

senses.definition: to pretend that something is true; to imagine what would happen if something were true

examples.x: Surely we should do something about it?

senses.definition: used with a negative to show that something surprises you and you do not want to believe it

examples.x: Surely you don't think I was responsible for this?

senses.definition: without doubt; certainly surely

examples.x: He knew that if help did not arrive soon they would surely die.

senses.definition: used to say ‘yes’ to somebody or to agree to something
an investigation of the opinions, behaviour, etc. of a particular group of people, which is usually done by asking them questions

examples.x: A recent survey showed 75 per cent of those questioned were in favour of the plan.
The survey revealed/found that…
to conduct/carry out/do/complete a survey

Another national survey conducted last year found the same result.
Roughly half of survey respondents express strong interest in additional education.
The results of the survey come as no surprise to us.

senses.definition: the act of examining and recording the measurements, features, etc. of an area of land in order to make a map or plan of it

examples.x: an aerial survey (= made by taking photographs from a plane, drone, etc.)

senses.definition: an examination of the condition of a house, etc., usually done for somebody who is thinking of buying it

examples.x: a detailed structural survey

senses.definition: a general study, view or description of something

examples.x: a comprehensive survey of modern music

senses.definition: to look carefully at the whole of something, especially in order to get a general impression of it

examples.x: The next morning we surveyed the damage caused by the fire.
