senses.definition: to study and give a general description of something

examples.x: This chapter briefly surveys the current state of European politics.

senses.definition: to investigate the opinions or behaviour of a group of people by asking them a series of questions

examples.x: We surveyed 500 smokers and found that over three quarters would like to give up.

senses.definition: to measure and record the features of an area of land, for example in order to make a map or in preparation for building
to examine a building to make sure it is in good condition

examples.x: Have the house surveyed before you decide whether to buy it.

senses.definition: to provide enough of what somebody/something needs in order to live or exist

senses.definition: to have a strong rhythm
if a party, etc. is swinging, there are a lot of people there having a good time is swinging
a swinging movement or rhythm

the swing of her hips

senses.definition: a change from one opinion or situation to another; the amount by which something changes

senses.definition: a seat for swinging on, hung from above on ropes or chains

senses.definition: the swinging movement you make with your arms and body when you hit the ball in the game of golf

examples.x: I need to work on my swing.

senses.definition: a type of jazz with a smooth rhythm, played especially by big dance bands in the 1930s

examples.x: a three-day campaign swing through California

senses.definition: a way of arguing in which two statements are used to prove that a third statement is true, for example: ‘All humans must die; I am a human; therefore I must die.’

examples.x: a sympathetic listener

senses.definition: easy to like

senses.definition: in a way that shows that you approve of somebody/something or that you share their views and are willing to support them

senses.definition: in a way that makes it easy to like somebody; in a pleasant way

senses.definition: to support somebody/something

senses.definition: to buy a newspaper or magazine regularly

examples.x: We take the ‘Express’.

senses.definition: to use something in order to work

senses.definition: to wear a particular size in shoes or clothes

senses.definition: to have enough space for something/somebody; to be able to hold or contain a particular quantity

senses.definition: to go over or around something

senses.definition: to use a particular method to find out people’s opinions

examples.x: to take a vote/poll/survey

senses.definition: to be successful; to work

senses.definition: to have or require something when used in a sentence or other structure

senses.definition: a scene or part of a film that is filmed at one time without stopping the camera

a new take on the Romeo and Juliet story (= a way of presenting it)

senses.definition: not bright

examples.x: the dim glow of the fire in the grate

senses.definition: where you cannot see well because there is not much light

examples.x: a dim room/street

senses.definition: that you cannot see well because there is not much light

examples.x: the dim outline of a house in the moonlight

senses.definition: not able to see well

examples.x: His eyesight is getting dim.

senses.definition: that you cannot remember or imagine clearly

senses.definition: not intelligent

senses.definition: not giving any reason to have hope; not good

senses.definition: connected with principles of right and wrong behaviour

senses.definition: to have ideas, words or images in your mind

senses.definition: to form an idea of something; to imagine something imagine

examples.x: We couldn't think where you'd gone.

senses.definition: used in questions to show that you are angry or surprised

senses.definition: an idea or opinion that is considered socially unacceptable or criminal
a group of people who are seen as trying to control people’s ideas and stop them from having their own opinions
the main point of an argument, a policy, etc.

examples.x: The thrust of his argument was that change was needed.

senses.definition: a sudden, strong movement that pushes something/somebody forward

examples.x: He killed her with a thrust of the knife.

senses.definition: the force that is produced by an engine to push a plane, rocket, etc. forward
a regular rise and fall in the level of the sea, caused by the pull of the moon and sun; the flow of water that happens as the sea rises and falls tide

examples.x: the ebb and flow of the tide
The tide is in/out.

senses.definition: the direction in which the opinion of a large number of people seems to be moving

examples.x: It takes courage to speak out against the tide of opinion.

a tide of optimism

senses.definition: a large amount of something unpleasant that is increasing and is difficult to control

examples.x: There is anxiety about the rising tide of crime.

senses.definition: a feeling that you suddenly have that gets stronger and stronger

examples.x: A tide of rage surged through her.

senses.definition: a time or season of the year

examples.x: Christmastide

senses.definition: to match or agree with something

examples.x: This evidence ties in closely with what we already know.

senses.definition: a slight argument between close friends or two people who love each other

examples.x: to have a tiff with somebody
It’s just a lovers’ tiff.

senses.definition: to go to see an important or powerful person to tell them that you disagree with them, that you want something, etc.
the part of a person that makes them able to be aware of things, to think and to feel

examples.x: the conscious/subconscious mind
There were all kinds of thoughts running through my mind.
There was no doubt in his mind that he'd get the job.
‘Drugs’ are associated in most people's minds with drug abuse.
She was in a disturbed state of mind.
I could not have complete peace of mind before they returned.
The campaign to win the hearts and minds of the public continues.
I felt refreshed in mind and body.

senses.definition: your ability to think and reason; your intelligence; the particular way that somebody thinks

examples.x: to have a brilliant/good/keen mind
a creative/evil/suspicious mind
She had a lively and enquiring mind.
His mind is as sharp as ever.
I've no idea how her mind works!
He had the body of a man and the mind of a child.
Their evidence might give us some insights into the criminal mind.

senses.definition: a person who is very intelligent

examples.x: She was one of the greatest minds of her generation.
a problem that has defeated the world's finest minds
Larry is one of the best trained minds in the industry.

senses.definition: your thoughts, interest, etc.

examples.x: Keep your mind on your work!
Your mind’s not on the job.
Her mind was completely occupied by the previous day's events.
The lecture dragged on and my mind wandered.
He gave his mind to the arrangements for the next day.
As for avoiding you, nothing could be further from my mind (= I was not thinking of it at all).

senses.definition: your ability to remember things

examples.x: When I saw the exam questions my mind just went blank (= I couldn't remember anything).
Sorry—your name has gone right out of my mind.
terrible images that will be imprinted on our minds forever

senses.definition: a method, style or manner of doing something

examples.x: I prefer to do things the easy way.
I love him and I think he feels the same way.
I'm sure we can find a way to make this work.
Using the subway is the only way to avoid the traffic.
That's no way to speak to your mother!
I'm not happy with this way of working.
It's not what you say, it's the way that you say it.
I hate the way she always criticizes me.
I told you we should have done it my way!
She dresses in the same way as her sister.
Infectious diseases can be acquired in several ways.
In this way, we can track the storms as they move across the ocean.
It works in the way you'd expect.
New technology has radically changed the way in which this work is done.
She writes in a way that is easy to understand.
I generally get what I want one way or another (= by some means).

senses.definition: a particular manner or style of behaviour

examples.x: They grinned at her in a friendly way.
It was not his way to admit that he had made a mistake.
Don't worry, if she seems quiet—it's just her way.
He was showing off, as is the way with adolescent boys.

senses.definition: the typical way of behaving and living of a particular group of people

examples.x: After ten years I'm used to the strange British ways.
She always said that the old ways were the best.

senses.definition: a route or road that you take in order to reach a place

examples.x: to ask somebody the way
Do you know the way?
Can you tell me the way to Leicester Square?
the best/quickest/shortest way from A to B
We went the long way round.

senses.definition: the route along which somebody/something is moving; the route that somebody/something would take if there was nothing stopping them/it

examples.x: Get out of my way! I'm in a hurry.
Riot police with shields were blocking the demonstrators' way.
Unfortunately they ran into a snowstorm along the way.
We fought our way through the dense vegetation.
We will eventually find a way out of the crisis.

senses.definition: a road, path or street for travelling along

examples.x: There's a way across the fields.

senses.definition: used in the names of streets

examples.x: 106 Headley Way

senses.definition: a particular direction; in a particular direction

examples.x: Which way did they go?
We just missed a car coming the other way.
Look both ways (= look left and right) before crossing the road.
Make sure that sign's the right way up.
The pipe could be moved a few inches either way.
Kids were running this way and that (= in all directions).
They decided to split the money four ways (= between four different people).
Which way (= for which party) are you going to vote?

senses.definition: a means of going into or leaving a place, such as a door or gate

examples.x: the way in/out
They escaped out the back way.

senses.definition: a distance or period of time between two points

examples.x: A little way up on the left is the Museum of Modern Art.
We had to go a long way before we found a place to eat.
September was a long way off.
You came all this way to see us?
The area's wine industry still has a way to go to full maturity.
We still have a ways to go.

senses.definition: an area, a part of a country, etc.

examples.x: I think he lives somewhere over Greenwich way.
I'll stop by and see you next time I'm down your way.

senses.definition: a particular aspect of something

examples.x: I have changed in every way.
It's been quite a day, one way and another (= for several reasons).

senses.definition: a particular condition or state

examples.x: The economy's in a bad way.
I don't know how we're going to manage, the way things are.

senses.definition: to begin doing or using something begin

examples.x: I start work at nine.
He's just started a new job.
The kids start school next week.
I only started (= began to read) this book yesterday.
We need to start (= begin using) a new jar of coffee.
It's a long story. Where shall I start?
Can you start (= a new job) on Monday?
It started to rain.
I was starting to feel tired.
Mistakes were starting to creep in.
She started laughing.
Suddenly things started happening.
It's time you started on your homework.
Let's start by reviewing what we did last week.
If you want to find out more, this website is a good place to start.

senses.definition: to begin happening; to make something begin happening start

examples.x: Work is due to start this weekend.
What time does the show start?
Have you any idea where the rumour started?
Who started the fire?

Do you start the day with a good breakfast?

The news started me thinking.

senses.definition: when you start a machine or a vehicle or it starts, it begins to operate start

examples.x: Start the engines!

I can't get the car started.
The car won't start.

senses.definition: to begin to exist; to make something begin to exist

examples.x: The company started in 1894 in Pennsylvania.

She started a business while she was still at school.
I decided to start a fashion blog.
They want to start a family (= to have children).

senses.definition: to begin from a particular place, amount or situation; to begin in a particular way

examples.x: The trail starts just outside the town.
Hotel prices start at €80 for a double room.
A sentence always starts with a capital letter.

The best professional musicians start young.

senses.definition: to begin, or to begin something such as a career, in a particular way that changed later

examples.x: She started as a secretary but ended up running the department.
It started as a hobby and grew from there.
The company started out with 30 employees.
I started off as a dishwasher making 25 cents an hour.

senses.definition: to begin a journey; to leave

examples.x: What time are we starting tomorrow?

senses.definition: to begin to move in a particular direction

examples.x: I started after her (= began to follow her) to tell her the news.
He started for the door, but I blocked his way.

senses.definition: to move suddenly and quickly because you are surprised or afraid

examples.x: The sudden noise made her start.

senses.definition: used during an argument or a discussion to show that you accept that somebody has answered your comment in a clever way and has gained an advantage by making a good point
a person who often causes trouble, especially by involving others in arguments or encouraging them to complain about people in authority
connected with facts rather than things that have been invented or guessed true

examples.x: Indicate whether the following statements are true or false.
Can you prove that what you say is true?
All the rumours turned out to be true.
Is it true she's leaving?
It is certainly true that money can't buy you happiness.
I think it would be true to say that the show was a success.
That's not strictly (= completely) true.
The novel is based on a true story.
Unfortunately, these findings do not hold true (= are not valid) for women and children.
Exercise can help in the development of social skills, and this is especially true for kids playing team sports.
The music is dull and uninspiring, and the same is true of the acting.
You never spoke a truer word (= used to emphasize that you agree with what somebody has just said).

senses.definition: real or exact, especially when this is different from how something seems

examples.x: the true face of war (= what it is really like rather than what people think it is like)
This project demonstrates the true value of teamwork.
The true cost of these experiments to the environment will not be known for years to come.
He reveals his true character to very few people.
I did not realize the true nature of their relationship.
She was unable to hide her true feelings for him.

senses.definition: having the qualities or characteristics of the thing mentioned

examples.x: It was true love between them.
He's a true gentleman.
The painting is a masterpiece in the truest sense of the word.
He is credited with inventing the first true helicopter.

senses.definition: used to admit that a particular fact or statement is correct, although you think that something else is more important While

examples.x: It's true that he could do the job, but would he fit in with the rest of the team?
It's perfectly true that I didn't help much, but I was busy.
‘We could get it cheaper.’ ‘True, but would it be as good?’
True enough, but that doesn't tell the whole story.

senses.definition: showing respect and support for a particular person or belief in a way that does not change, even in different situations

examples.x: a true friend
She has always been true to herself (= done what she thought was good, right, etc.).
He was true to his word (= did what he promised to do).
Many were executed for remaining true to their principles.
Knights swore to be true to their lord.

senses.definition: being an accurate version or copy of something

examples.x: The movie is not true to the book.
The painting is a true likeness of her.

senses.definition: straight and accurate

examples.x: His aim was true (= he hit the target).

senses.definition: giving your opinions about something in a loud and aggressive way

examples.x: a tub-thumping speech

senses.definition: the act of giving your opinions about something in a loud and aggressive way
a situation in which there is a lot of sudden change, trouble, argument and sometimes violence

examples.x: a period of turbulence in the country’s history
The country is facing a summer of political turbulence.

senses.definition: a series of sudden and violent changes in the direction that air or water is moving in have/​take

examples.x: We experienced severe turbulence during the flight.

senses.definition: in which there is a lot of sudden change, trouble, argument and sometimes violence

examples.x: a short and turbulent career in politics
a turbulent part of the world
turbulent emotions

senses.definition: changing direction suddenly and violently

examples.x: The aircraft is designed to withstand turbulent conditions.
a turbulent sea/storm (= caused by turbulent water/air)
They jumped off the cliff into the turbulent waters below.

senses.definition: noisy and/or difficult to control

examples.x: a turbulent crowd

senses.definition: a violent situation between two groups of people who disagree about who should control a particular area, activity or business

examples.x: a vicious turf war between rival gangs of drug dealers

senses.definition: the amount of time it takes to unload a ship or plane at the end of one journey and load it again for the next one

examples.x: Budget airlines rely on very fast turnaround times.

senses.definition: the amount of time it takes to do a piece of work that you have been given and return it

examples.x: Customers want a quick turnaround between order and delivery.

senses.definition: a situation in which something changes from bad to good

examples.x: a turnaround in the economy

senses.definition: a complete change in somebody’s opinion, behaviour, etc.

examples.x: They remain suspicious about the government’s turnaround on education policy.

senses.definition: the amount of time it takes to unload a ship or plane at the end of one journey and load it again for the next one
the amount of time it takes to do a piece of work that you have been given and return it
a situation in which something changes from bad to good

examples.x: a turnround in the economy

senses.definition: a complete change in somebody’s opinion, behaviour, etc.

examples.x: They remain suspicious about the government's turnround on education policy.

senses.definition: a short struggle, fight or argument especially in order to get something

examples.x: He was injured during a tussle for the ball.
There was a legal tussle over the closure of the hospital.
She had a brief tussle with her conscience before telling the whole story.

senses.definition: to fight or compete with somebody/something, especially in order to get something

examples.x: The children were tussling with one another for the ball.

senses.definition: complete agreement about something among a group of people

examples.x: There is no unanimity of opinion among the medical profession on this subject.
We won’t all agree, but we need to achieve a degree of unanimity.

senses.definition: if a decision or an opinion is unanimous, it is agreed or shared by everyone in a group unanimous

examples.x: a unanimous vote
unanimous support
The decision was not unanimous.
Unanimous agreement must be reached for this plan to go ahead.
The jury reached a unanimous verdict of ‘not guilty’.
She was the unanimous choice of the selection committee.

senses.definition: if a group of people are unanimous, they all agree about something unanimous

examples.x: Local people are unanimous in their opposition to the proposed new road.
The committee were unanimous in rejecting the proposal.

senses.definition: an unanswerable argument, etc. is one that nobody can question or disagree with unanswerable

examples.x: They presented an unanswerable case for more investment.

senses.definition: an unanswerable question is one that has no answer or that you cannot answer unanswerable
that nobody can disagree with

examples.x: unarguable proof

senses.definition: in a way that nobody can disagree with

examples.x: She is unarguably one of the country's finest athletes.

senses.definition: unwilling to change your opinions, decisions, etc.

examples.x: Her father was a stern unbending man.

senses.definition: an unbridgeable gap or difference between two people or groups or their opinions is one that cannot be closed or made less wide unbridgeable

examples.x: Owing to seemingly unbridgeable political differences, there has been little dialogue between the two sides.

senses.definition: that cannot be questioned or argued with; that cannot be challenged

examples.x: unchallengeable evidence

senses.definition: not willing to talk to other people or give opinions
an unfair belief about a group of people that you are not aware of and that affects your behaviour and decisions

examples.x: Removing unconscious bias in the recruitment process is an important way of improving workforce diversity.
They recognize the need for unconscious bias training as a starting point.

senses.definition: without any opposition or argument Uncontested

examples.x: These claims have not gone uncontested.
She was appointed to the post following an uncontested election (= in which there were no other candidates).
The uncontested divorce was finalized on March 17.

senses.definition: to support or form the basis of an argument, a claim, etc.

examples.x: The report is underpinned by extensive research.

senses.definition: to support a wall and make it stronger by putting metal, concrete (= a hard building material), etc. under it
something that supports or forms the basis of an argument, a claim, etc.

examples.x: the theoretical underpinnings of the study

senses.definition: the act of supporting a wall and making it stronger by putting metal, concrete (= a hard building material), etc. under it; the metal, concrete, etc. that supports the wall

examples.x: The only way to save the building is through extensive underpinning.

senses.definition: the expression of strong dislike of or opposition to something; a statement or an action that shows this

examples.x: to hold/organize/join a protest
violent/anti-war protests
The riot began as a peaceful protest.
mass/street protests
a protest march/movement
Unions have called for a day of protest on 24 February.
The announcement raised a storm of protest.
There have been mounting protests at the treatment of asylum seekers by the government.
The director resigned in protest at the decision.
People rioted in the streets in protest.
protests over plans to close the museum
She accepted the charge without protest.
The workers staged a protest against the proposed changes in their contracts.
They have decided not to attend the Bonn conference as a protest.
The strike began the day before as a protest against the proposed cuts.
The building work will go ahead, despite protests from local residents.
The country has undergone two weeks of protests by workers and students.

senses.definition: expressing your opinion or intention very clearly and strongly plain

examples.x: an unequivocal rejection
The answer was an unequivocal ‘no’.

senses.definition: to show, by clicking a special button, that you disagree with something on social media, a news website, a blog, etc.
to not be liked by people; to be unpopular

examples.x: The article suggests his character was unliked by many.

senses.definition: bad feeling or arguments between people

examples.x: I’d rather avoid any unpleasantness with the neighbours.

senses.definition: not influenced by an unreasonable fear or dislike of something/somebody; willing to consider different ideas and opinions
that may change; making people uncertain about what might happen

senses.definition: not calm or relaxed

examples.x: They all felt restless and unsettled.

senses.definition: that continues without any agreement being reached
not yet paid
not stated; not said in words but understood or agreed between people Unspoken

senses.definition: not stated; not said in words but understood or agreed between people

examples.x: Their reasoning was based on a set of unstated assumptions.

senses.definition: not feeling or showing any sympathy

senses.definition: not in agreement with something; not supporting an idea, aim, etc.

senses.definition: not easy to like; unpleasant
without feeling or showing any sympathy

senses.definition: in a way that is not in agreement with something or does not support an idea, aim, etc.

examples.x: Her complaint was treated unsympathetically.

senses.definition: in a way that makes it difficult to like somebody; in an unpleasant way

examples.x: The character was portrayed unsympathetically.

senses.definition: a situation in which people shout and make a lot of noise because they are angry or upset about something

examples.x: The room was in (an) uproar.

senses.definition: a situation in which there is a lot of public criticism and angry argument about something that somebody has said or done

examples.x: The article caused (an) uproar.

senses.definition: to show that you agree with an online article or comment by using a particular icon

senses.definition: an act of showing that you agree with an online article or comment by using a particular icon

examples.x: You definitely get an upvote from me.

senses.definition: to keep changing your opinion or thoughts about something, especially in a way that annoys other people

examples.x: The country’s leaders are still vacillating between confrontation and compromise.

senses.definition: the act of often changing your opinion or thoughts about something, especially in a way that annoys other people

examples.x: problems of vacillation and delay in the government

senses.definition: not influenced by personal opinions
a judgement about how good or important something is, based on personal opinions rather than facts

examples.x: Evolutionary psychology does not make a value judgement about the way we behave.

senses.definition: influenced by personal opinions

examples.x: ‘Freedom fighter’ is a value-laden word.

senses.definition: a long period of violence between two families or groups, in which people are murdered in return for previous murders
a long argument or campaign in which one person or group does or says things to harm another

examples.x: He has accused the media of pursuing a vendetta against him.

senses.definition: to allow fresh air to enter and move around a room, building, etc.

examples.x: The bathroom is ventilated by means of an extractor fan.

a well-ventilated room

senses.definition: to express your feelings or opinions publicly
an official judgement made in court or at an inquest (= an official investigation into somebody's death) break/​violate/​obey/​uphold

examples.x: Has the jury reached a verdict?

senses.definition: a decision that you make or an opinion that you give about something, after you have tested it or considered it carefully

examples.x: Well, what's your verdict?

senses.definition: what you can see from a particular place or position, especially beautiful countryside view

examples.x: There were magnificent views of the surrounding countryside.

a sea/mountain view

senses.definition: used when you are talking about whether you can see something or whether something can be seen in a particular situation sight

senses.definition: a personal opinion about something; an attitude towards something according to

senses.definition: a way of understanding or thinking about something

the Christian view of the world

senses.definition: an occasion when a video is watched online

senses.definition: a photograph or picture that shows an interesting place or scene

senses.definition: a special chance to see or admire something

senses.definition: connected with the voice spoken

the vocal organs (= the tongue, lips, etc.)

to speak in a deep/soft/loud voice

senses.definition: having a voice of the type mentioned

examples.x: low-voiced
squeaky-voiced

the voice of reason/sanity/conscience

senses.definition: an organization that expresses the opinion of a particular section of society

examples.x: The Royal Society is the voice of the British science establishment.

senses.definition: the form of a verb that shows whether the subject of a sentence performs the action (the active voice) or is affected by it (the passive voice)

examples.x: Can you turn this sentence into the passive voice?

examples.x: to voice complaints/criticisms/doubts/objections, etc.

senses.definition: to produce a sound with a movement of your vocal cords as well as your breath
a complete change of opinion or plan

examples.x: This represents a volte-face in government thinking.

senses.definition: the opinion of members of the public, especially when it is broadcast or published; the process of asking members of the public for their opinion on something in order to broadcast or publish it

examples.x: to do a vox pop
a series of short vox pops with ordinary Londoners

senses.definition: to enter a fight, a discussion or an argument in an aggressive or not very sensitive way

examples.x: The police waded into the crowd with batons.

senses.definition: to enter a fight, a discussion or an argument in an aggressive or not very sensitive way

examples.x: The police waded into the crowd with batons.

senses.definition: not physically strong weak

senses.definition: that cannot support a lot of weight; likely to break

senses.definition: easy to influence; not having much power

examples.x: weak tea

senses.definition: not easily seen or heard

senses.definition: not good at something

senses.definition: that people are not likely to believe or be persuaded by

senses.definition: done without enthusiasm or energy

senses.definition: the part of a person’s character, an argument, etc. that is easy to attack or criticize

examples.x: The team's weak points are in defence.

senses.definition: a weak verb forms the past tense and past participle by adding a regular ending and not by changing a vowel. In English this is done by adding -d, -ed or -t (for example walk, walked). weak
used when there is no stress on the word. For example, the weak form of and is /ən/ or /n/, as in fish and chips /fɪʃ ən tʃɪps/.
to have your weight measured, especially before a contest, race, etc.

examples.x: Both boxers weighed in at several pounds below the limit.

senses.definition: to form an opinion of somebody by watching or talking to them

examples.x: It was obvious that she was cautiously weighing me up.

senses.definition: something that you do or say to somebody when they arrive, especially something that makes them feel you are happy to see them

examples.x: to get/receive a welcome

a speech/smile of welcome

senses.definition: the way that people react to something, which shows their opinion of it

examples.x: This new comedy deserves a warm welcome.

senses.definition: used to express surprise, anger or relief

examples.x: Well, well—I would never have guessed it!

senses.definition: used to show that you accept that something cannot be changed

examples.x: Well, it can't be helped.

senses.definition: used to agree to something, rather unwillingly

examples.x: Well, I suppose I could fit you in at 3.45.

examples.x: Well, as I was saying…

senses.definition: used to say that something is uncertain

used when you are saying that something is likely

examples.x: No doubt she'll call us when she gets there.

senses.definition: used when you are saying that something is certainly true

examples.x: He's made some great movies. There's no doubt about it.

senses.definition: a state of feeling or being happy or satisfied fun

examples.x: His eyes lit up with pleasure.

senses.definition: the activity of enjoying yourself, especially in contrast to working entertainment

examples.x: Are you in Paris on business or pleasure?
a pleasure boat/trip

senses.definition: a thing that makes you happy or satisfied pleasure

examples.x: the simple pleasures of the countryside
the pleasures and pains of everyday life

examples.cf: it is a pleasure to do something

senses.definition: a particular aspect or detail of something

senses.definition: to defeat somebody in a fight, a contest or an argument worse

examples.x: She couldn't bear to be worsted in a fight.

senses.definition: used in polite offers or invitations

examples.x: Would you like a sandwich?

senses.definition: used to say what you like, love, hate, etc.

examples.cf: would like, love, hate, prefer, etc. something

examples.cf: in order that somebody/something would do something

examples.x: I wish that you'd be quiet for a minute.

senses.definition: used to show that somebody/something was not willing or refused to do something

examples.x: She wouldn't change it, even though she knew it was wrong.
My car wouldn't start this morning.

senses.definition: used to ask somebody politely to do something

examples.x: Would you mind leaving us alone for a few minutes?
Would you open the door for me, please?

senses.definition: used to give opinions that you are not certain about

examples.x: I would imagine the job will take about two days.
I'd say he was about fifty.

senses.definition: used to give advice

examples.x: I wouldn't have any more to drink, if I were you.

senses.definition: used for talking about things that often happened in the past

examples.x: When my parents were away, my grandmother would take care of me.
He'd always be the first to offer to help.

senses.definition: used for talking about behaviour that you think is typical

examples.x: ‘She said it was your fault.’ ‘Well, she would say that, wouldn't she? She's never liked me.’

senses.definition: used to express a strong wish modal verbs

examples.x: Would that he had lived to see it.

senses.definition: an argument that is complicated and continues over a long period of time wring

examples.x: a legal wrangle between the company and their suppliers
He is currently locked in a bitter wrangle with his wife over custody of the children.

senses.definition: to argue angrily and usually for a long time about something wring

examples.x: They're still wrangling over the financial details.
Police officers wrangled with the youths and then fired tear gas to force them back.
Britain was still wrangling with Brussels about the terms of its departure from the EU.

senses.definition: the process of conducting a complicated argument with somebody over a long period of time

examples.x: After six months of legal wrangling, the case was no further forward.

senses.definition: to write to an organization or a company, for example to ask about something or to express an opinion

examples.x: I'll write in for more information.
She wrote in to the BBC to complain.

senses.definition: the lowest part of the leg, below the ankle, on which a person or an animal stands feat

examples.x: My feet are aching.
She kicked the ball with her right foot.
He's broken several bones in his left foot.
The whole audience rose to its feet (= stood up) and cheered.
to leap/jump/spring to your feet (= to stand up quickly and easily)
to scramble/struggle/stagger to your feet (= to stand up slowly and with difficulty)
We came on foot (= we walked).
I've been on my feet (= standing or walking around) all day.
Come on lads—on your feet and do some work!
walking around the house in bare feet (= not wearing shoes or socks)
We were stamping our feet (= hitting them on the ground) to keep warm.
Please wipe your feet (= your shoes) on the mat.
The hot sand burned the soles of my feet.
He is currently resting a foot injury.
a foot pump (= operated using your foot, not your hand)
a foot passenger (= one who travels on a ferry without a car)

senses.definition: having or using the type or number of foot/feet mentioned

examples.x: bare-footed
four-footed
a left-footed shot into the corner

senses.definition: the part of a sock, stocking, etc. that covers the foot
a unit for measuring length equal to 12 inches or 30.48 centimetres

examples.x: a six-foot high wall
We're flying at 35 000 feet.
‘How tall are you?’ ‘Five foot nine (= five feet and nine inches).’
The town was under several feet of water (= the water was several feet deep).
We had over a foot of snow in a few hours (= the snow was over a foot deep).
The store has 600 square feet of retail space.

senses.definition: the lowest part of something; the base or bottom of something bottom

examples.x: The city now reaches to the foot of the surrounding mountains.
At the foot of the stairs she turned to face him.
See the foot of this page for a partial bibliography.
The team remains stuck at the foot of the table (= with fewer points than all the other teams).

senses.definition: the further or lower end of something

examples.x: The nurse hung a chart at the foot of the bed (= the part of the bed where your feet normally are when you are lying in it).
He sat at the foot of the table.

senses.definition: a unit of rhythm in a line of poetry containing one stressed syllable and one or more syllables without stress. Each of the four divisions in the following line is a foot

examples.x: For men / may come / and men / may go.

senses.definition: yes
yes
used to answer a question and say that something is correct or true

examples.x: ‘Is this your car?’ ‘Yes, it is.’
‘Are you coming? Yes or no?’

senses.definition: used to show that you agree with what has been said

examples.x: ‘I enjoyed her latest novel.’ ‘Yes, me too.’
‘It's an excellent hotel.’ ‘Yes, but (= I don't completely agree) it's too expensive.’
In reply to his question, most of them answered yes.

senses.definition: used to disagree with something negative that somebody has just said

examples.x: ‘I've never met her before.’ ‘Yes, you have.’

senses.definition: used to agree to a request or to give permission

examples.x: ‘Dad, can I borrow the car?’ ‘Yes, but be careful.’
We're hoping that they will say yes to our proposals.

senses.definition: used to accept an offer or invitation

examples.x: ‘Would you like a drink?’ ‘Yes, please/thanks.’

senses.definition: used for asking somebody what they want

examples.x: Yes? How can I help you?

senses.definition: used for replying politely when somebody calls you

examples.x: ‘Waiter!’ ‘Yes, sir?’

senses.definition: used to show that you have just remembered something

examples.x: Where did I put the keys? Oh yes—in my pocket!

senses.definition: used to encourage somebody to continue speaking

examples.x: ‘I’m going to Paris this weekend.’ ‘Yes…’

senses.definition: used to show that you do not believe what somebody has said

examples.x: ‘Sorry I'm late—the bus didn't come.’ ‘Oh yes?’

senses.definition: used to emphasize what you have just said

examples.x: Mrs Smith has just won £2 million—yes!—£2 million!

senses.definition: used to show that you are excited or extremely pleased about something that you have done or something that has happened

examples.x: ‘They've scored another goal.’ ‘Yes!!’

senses.definition: used to show that you are impatient or annoyed about something

examples.x: ‘Hurry up—it's late.’ ‘Yes, yes—I'm coming.’

senses.definition: an answer that shows that you agree with an idea, a statement, etc.; a person who says ‘yes’

examples.x: I need a simple yes or no to my questions.
There will be two ballot boxes—one for yesses and one for noes.
I'll put you down as a yes.
When the villagers were asked if they wanted the factory to be built, the answer was a resounding yes.

senses.definition: used to emphasize your opinion or say that you agree very strongly

examples.x: Yessir, she was beautiful.

senses.definition: to speak or tell somebody something, using words said

examples.x: ‘Hello!’ she said.
‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.
A legendary football coach once said, ‘Winning is everything.’

senses.definition: to repeat words, phrases, etc.

examples.x: to say a prayer
Try to say that line with more conviction.

senses.definition: to give particular information or instructions

examples.x: The notice said ‘Keep Out’.
The clock said three o'clock.
The instructions say (that) we should leave it to set for four hours.
The book doesn't say where he was born.
The guidebook says to turn left.

senses.definition: to express an opinion on something

examples.x: Say what you like (= although you disagree) about her, she's a fine singer.
I'll say this for them, they're a very efficient company.
Anna thinks I'm lazy—what do you say (= what is your opinion)?
I can't say I blame her for resigning (= I think she was right).
I have to say I enjoyed every minute.
I say (= suggest) we go without them.
I wouldn't say they were rich (= in my opinion they are not rich).
That's not to say it's a bad movie (= it is good but it is not without faults).
It's hard to say what caused the accident.
It's difficult to say whether the story is true.
‘When will it be finished?’ ‘I couldn't say (= I don't know).’
Is it worth it? I would say not.

senses.definition: to make thoughts, feelings, etc. clear to somebody by using words, looks, movements, etc.

examples.x: His angry glance said it all.
Just what is the artist trying to say in her work?
The museum's architects have managed to say something about our national story.

senses.definition: to show, sometimes indirectly, what somebody/something is like

examples.x: That says it all really, doesn't it? (= it shows clearly what is true)
The incident says an awful lot about his character.
This says to me that there is more here than you are letting on.

senses.definition: to suggest or give something as an example or a possibility

examples.x: You could learn the basics in, let's say, three months.
Let’s take any writer, say (= for example) Dickens…
Say you lose your job: what would you do then?
Just say he refuses to talk to you.

senses.definition: to begin doing or using something begin

examples.x: I start work at nine.
He's just started a new job.
The kids start school next week.
I only started (= began to read) this book yesterday.
We need to start (= begin using) a new jar of coffee.
It's a long story. Where shall I start?
Can you start (= a new job) on Monday?
It started to rain.
I was starting to feel tired.
Mistakes were starting to creep in.
She started laughing.
Suddenly things started happening.
It's time you started on your homework.
Let's start by reviewing what we did last week.
If you want to find out more, this website is a good place to start.

senses.definition: to begin happening; to make something begin happening start

examples.x: Work is due to start this weekend.
What time does the show start?
Have you any idea where the rumour started?
Who started the fire?
I'm ready to start the process of writing.
Do you start the day with a good breakfast?
You're always trying to start an argument.
The news started me thinking.

senses.definition: when you start a machine or a vehicle or it starts, it begins to operate start

examples.x: Start the engines!
He started the recording.
I can't get the car started.
The car won't start.

senses.definition: to begin to exist; to make something begin to exist

examples.x: The company started in 1894 in Pennsylvania.
There are a lot of small businesses starting up in that area.
She started a business while she was still at school.
I decided to start a fashion blog.
They want to start a family (= to have children).
He decided to start up his own film festival.

senses.definition: to begin from a particular place, amount or situation; to begin in a particular way

examples.x: The trail starts just outside the town.
Hotel prices start at €80 for a double room.
A sentence always starts with a capital letter.
The evening started badly when the speaker failed to turn up.
The best professional musicians start young.

senses.definition: to begin, or to begin something such as a career, in a particular way that changed later

examples.x: She started as a secretary but ended up running the department.
It started as a hobby and grew from there.
The company started out with 30 employees.
I started off as a dishwasher making 25 cents an hour.
He started life as a teacher before turning to journalism.
She started her career working for the BBC.

senses.definition: to begin a journey; to leave

examples.x: What time are we starting tomorrow?

senses.definition: to begin to move in a particular direction

examples.x: I started after her (= began to follow her) to tell her the news.
He started for the door, but I blocked his way.

senses.definition: to move suddenly and quickly because you are surprised or afraid

examples.x: The sudden noise made her start.

senses.definition: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it knows

examples.x: No one knows the answer.
I need to know your name.
The truth about what happened is not yet known.
All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).
I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.
We know from experience that turning a hobby into a business is not easy.
I know for a fact (that) he didn't go to the party.
‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’
‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’
‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’
As you know, Emma and I are old friends.
‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)
‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).
It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.
I knew where he was hiding.
No one knows for sure who did it.
You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?
I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.
I know next to nothing (= know almost nothing) about opera.
I know of someone who can help us.
‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’
Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?
We know her to be honest.
Strobe lights are known to cause seizures.

senses.definition: to realize, understand or be aware of something

examples.x: As soon as I walked in the room I knew (that) something was wrong.
She knew she was dying.
‘Martin was lying all the time.’ ‘I should have known.’
I knew perfectly well what she meant.
I know exactly how you feel.
This case is hopeless and he knows it (= although he will not admit it).

senses.definition: to feel certain about something knew

examples.x: He knew (that) he could trust her.
I know it's here somewhere!
I know things will turn out all right.
I don't know that I can finish it by next week.
I just knew that it was something I wanted to do.
‘You were right—someone's been spreading rumours about you.’ ‘I knew it!’
‘She's the worst player in the team.’ ‘Oh, I don't know (= I am not sure that I agree)—she played well yesterday.’

senses.definition: to be familiar with a person, place, thing, etc.

examples.x: I've known David for 20 years.
Do you two know each other (= have you met before)?
She was a secretary when I first knew her.
She's very nice when you get to know her.
Knowing Ben, we could be waiting a long time (= it is typical of him to be late).
This man is known to the police (= as a criminal).
I don’t know anyone in Oxford.
I know Paris well.
Do you know the play (= have you seen or read it before)?
How many of your neighbours do you know by name?
The new rules could mean the end of football as we know it (= in the form that we are familiar with).

senses.definition: to have learned a skill or language and be able to use it

examples.x: Do you know any Japanese?
Do you know how to use spreadsheets?

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something is a particular type of person or thing or has particular characteristics

examples.x: He has become widely known as an expert in child psychology.
It's known as the most dangerous part of the city.
She is best known for her work on the human brain.
He is internationally known for his work with vaccines.
He's known to be an outstanding physicist.

senses.definition: to give somebody/something a particular name or title

examples.x: Iran was formerly known as Persia.
The H5N1 virus is more commonly known as bird flu.
Peter Wilson, also known as ‘The Tiger’

examples.cf: be known as somebody/something to somebody
examples.x: He was known as Bonzo to his friends.
The country was not yet known by the name of England.

senses.definition: to be able to recognize somebody/something identify

examples.x: I couldn't see who was speaking, but I knew the voice.
She knows a bargain when she sees one.

senses.definition: to understand the difference between one person or thing and another

examples.x: I hope we have taught our children to know right from wrong.

senses.definition: to have seen, heard or experienced something

examples.x: I’ve never known it (to) snow in July before.
He has been known to spend all morning in the bathroom.

senses.definition: to have personal experience of something

examples.x: He has known both poverty and wealth.
She may be successful now, but she has known what it is like to be poor.
She thought she would never know the joy of seeing a child grow up in her care.

senses.definition: to think about something carefully, especially in order to make a decision is about

examples.x: I'd like some time to consider.
She is considering her options.
Let us consider the facts.
We are considering various possibilities.
He was seriously considering an appeal.
a carefully considered response
The company is being actively considered as a potential partner (= it is thought possible that it could become one).
Have you considered starting your own business?
We need to consider how the law might be reformed.
He was considering what to do next.
The court must consider whether the employer was negligent.
We are considering her for the job of designer.

senses.definition: to think of somebody/something in a particular way regard

examples.x: I consider her a friend.
The award is considered a great honour.
He considers it his duty.

examples.cf: consider somebody/something to be, have, etc. something
examples.x: She is widely considered to be the greatest player ever.
Who do you consider to be responsible for the accident?
He's generally considered to have the finest tenor voice in the country.
He considers himself an expert on the subject.
They will take any steps they consider necessary.
The size and design of the proposed new building are not considered appropriate for the site.
You should consider this as a long-term investment.
She considers that it is too early to form a definite conclusion.
It is considered that the proposed development would create much-needed jobs.

senses.definition: to think about something, especially the feelings of other people, and be influenced by it when making a decision, etc.

examples.x: You should consider other people before you act.

senses.definition: to look carefully at somebody/something

examples.x: He stood there, considering the painting.

senses.definition: to speak or tell somebody something, using words said

examples.x: ‘Hello!’ she said.
‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.
A legendary football coach once said, ‘Winning is everything.’

senses.definition: to repeat words, phrases, etc.

examples.x: to say a prayer
Try to say that line with more conviction.

senses.definition: to give particular information or instructions

examples.x: The notice said ‘Keep Out’.
The clock said three o'clock.
The instructions say (that) we should leave it to set for four hours.
The book doesn't say where he was born.
The guidebook says to turn left.

senses.definition: to express an opinion on something

examples.x: Say what you like (= although you disagree) about her, she's a fine singer.
I'll say this for them, they're a very efficient company.
Anna thinks I'm lazy—what do you say (= what is your opinion)?
I can't say I blame her for resigning (= I think she was right).
I have to say I enjoyed every minute.
I say (= suggest) we go without them.
I wouldn't say they were rich (= in my opinion they are not rich).
That's not to say it's a bad movie (= it is good but it is not without faults).
It's hard to say what caused the accident.
It's difficult to say whether the story is true.
‘When will it be finished?’ ‘I couldn't say (= I don't know).’
Is it worth it? I would say not.

senses.definition: to make thoughts, feelings, etc. clear to somebody by using words, looks, movements, etc.

examples.x: His angry glance said it all.
Just what is the artist trying to say in her work?
The museum's architects have managed to say something about our national story.

senses.definition: to show, sometimes indirectly, what somebody/something is like

examples.x: That says it all really, doesn't it? (= it shows clearly what is true)
The incident says an awful lot about his character.
This says to me that there is more here than you are letting on.

senses.definition: to suggest or give something as an example or a possibility

examples.x: You could learn the basics in, let's say, three months.
Let’s take any writer, say (= for example) Dickens…
Say you lose your job: what would you do then?
Just say he refuses to talk to you.

senses.definition: to give information to somebody by speaking or writing Say

examples.x: He told the news to everybody he saw.
He told everybody he saw the news.
Did she tell you her name?
What did I tell you? (= you should have listened to my advice)
‘Come closer,’ she said, ‘I want to tell you something’.
Why wasn't I told about the accident?
They’ve told us (that) they’re not coming.
I told him straight (= in a direct way) that I wasn't voting for him.
He later told the court that he had returned the money.
I kept telling myself (that) everything was OK.
Are you telling me you didn't have any help with this? (= I don't believe what you have said)
Tell me where you live.
‘I'm ready to go now,’ he told her.
'We hope that there will be some progress,' he told reporters.

senses.definition: to give information about something

examples.x: The advertisement told us very little about the product.
This gauge tells you how much fuel you have left.
The sound of his breathing told her (that) he was asleep.

senses.definition: to express something in words

examples.x: to tell stories/jokes/lies
Are you sure you're telling the truth?
I can't tell you how happy I am.
We'd go fishing and she'd tell me stories.
All of them had an interesting story to tell.

senses.definition: to let somebody know a secret

examples.x: Promise you won't tell.
‘Who are you going out with tonight?’ ‘That would be telling!’ (= it's a secret)

senses.definition: to order or advise somebody to do something order

examples.x: He was told to sit down and wait.
There was a sign telling motorists to slow down.
I kept telling myself to keep calm.
I specifically told you to be here on time.
Do what I tell you.
Children must do as they're told.
Don't tell me what to do!
The doctor told me (that) I should eat less fat.

senses.definition: to know, see or judge something correctly

examples.x: I think he's happy. It's hard to tell.
As far as I can tell, she's enjoying the course.
‘That's not an original.’ ‘How can you tell?’
I could tell (that) he was angry from his expression.
The only way to tell if you like something is by trying it.
It's too early to tell how popular this service will be.
It's impossible to tell exactly where the problem is.

senses.definition: to recognize the difference between one thing or person and another

examples.x: It was hard to tell the difference between the two versions.
Can you tell Tom from his twin brother?
Can you tell this copy from the original?
It's difficult to tell them apart.
The kittens look exactly alike—how can you tell which is which?
I couldn't tell who was meant to be the chairman.

senses.definition: to have an effect on somebody/something, especially a bad one

examples.x: The strain was beginning to tell on the rescue team.
